text: This attempt succeeds as well as we could desire, and promises to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: metaphysics, in its first part--that is, where it is occupied with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: result, and one which, to all appearance, militates against the great
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: end of metaphysics, as treated in the second part. For we come to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conclusion that our faculty of cognition is unable to transcend the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits of possible experience; and yet this is precisely the most
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: essential object of this science. The estimate of our rational cognition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a priori at which we arrive is that it has only to do with phenomena,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and that things in themselves, while possessing a real existence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: lie beyond its sphere. Here we are enabled to put the justice of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: estimate to the test. For that which of necessity impels us to transcend
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the limits of experience and of all phenomena is the unconditioned,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which reason absolutely requires in things as they are in themselves,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in order to complete the series of conditions. Now, if it appears that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when, on the one hand, we assume that our cognition conforms to its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects as things in themselves, the unconditioned cannot be thought
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without contradiction, and that when, on the other hand, we assume that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: themselves, beyond the range of our cognition.*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: This experiment of pure reason has a great
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This attempt to introduce a complete revolution in the procedure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of metaphysics, after the example of the geometricians and natural
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophers, constitutes the aim of the Critique of Pure Speculative
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Reason. It is a treatise on the method to be followed, not a system of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the science itself. But, at the same time, it marks out and defines both
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the external boundaries and the internal structure of this science.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For pure speculative reason has this peculiarity, that, in choosing the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: various objects of thought, it is able to define the limits of its own
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: faculties, and even to give a complete enumeration of the possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: modes of proposing problems to itself, and thus to sketch out the entire
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: system of metaphysics. For, on the one hand, in cognition a priori,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nothing must be attributed to the objects but what the thinking subject
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: derives from itself; and, on the other hand, reason is, in regard to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the principles of cognition, a perfectly distinct, independent unity, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which, as in an organized body, every member exists for the sake of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the others, and all for the sake of each, so that no principle can be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: viewed, with safety, in one relationship, unless it is, at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time, viewed in relation to the total use of pure reason. Hence, too,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: metaphysics has this singular advantage--an advantage which falls to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: lot of no other science which has to do with objects--that, if once it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is conducted into the sure path of science, by means of this criticism,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it can then take in the whole sphere of its cognitions, and can thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complete its work, and leave it for the use of posterity, as a capital
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which can never receive fresh accessions. For metaphysics has to deal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only with principles and with the limitations of its own employment as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determined by these principles. To this perfection it is, therefore,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: bound, as the fundamental science, to attain, and to it the maxim may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: justly be applied:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Nil actum reputans, si quid superesset agendum.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But, it will be asked, what kind of a treasure is this that we propose
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to bequeath to posterity? What is the real value of this system of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: metaphysics, purified by criticism, and thereby reduced to a permanent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition? A cursory view of the present work will lead to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supposition that its use is merely negative, that it only serves to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: warn us against venturing, with speculative reason, beyond the limits
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of experience. This is, in fact, its primary use. But this, at once,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assumes a positive value, when we observe that the principles with which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculative reason endeavours to transcend its limits lead inevitably,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not to the extension, but to the contraction of the use of reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inasmuch as they threaten to extend the limits of sensibility, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is their proper sphere, over the entire realm of thought and, thus,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to supplant the pure (practical) use of reason. So far, then, as this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: criticism is occupied in confining speculative reason within its proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: bounds, it is only negative; but, inasmuch as it thereby, at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time, removes an obstacle which impedes and even threatens to destroy
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the use of practical reason, it possesses a positive and very important
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: value. In order to admit this, we have only to be convinced that there
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is an absolutely necessary use of pure reason--the moral use--in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it inevitably transcends the limits of sensibility, without the aid
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of speculation, requiring only to be insured against the effects of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculation which would involve it in contradiction with itself. To deny
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the positive advantage of the service which this criticism renders
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the violence which citizen has to apprehend from citizen, that so each
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: may pursue his vocation in peace and security. That space and time are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only forms of sensible intuition, and hence are only conditions of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of things, except in so far as a corresponding intuition can be given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to these conceptions; that, accordingly, we can have no cognition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an object, as a thing in itself, but only as an object of sensible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition, that is, as phenomenon--all this is proved in the analytical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: part of the Critique; and from this the limitation of all possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculative cognition to the mere objects of experience, follows as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that, while we surrender the power of cognizing, we still reserve the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: power of thinking objects, as things in themselves.* For, otherwise,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: something that appears--which would be absurd. Now let us suppose, for a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: take it. Suppose now, on the other hand, that we have undertaken this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: criticism, and have learnt that an object may be taken in two senses,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: first, as a phenomenon, secondly, as a thing in itself; and that,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to the deduction of the conceptions of the understanding, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle of causality has reference only to things in the first sense.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We then see how it does not involve any contradiction to assert, on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one hand, that the will, in the phenomenal sphere--in visible action--is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessarily obedient to the law of nature, and, in so far, not free;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and, on the other hand, that, as belonging to a thing in itself, it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not subject to that law, and, accordingly, is free. Now, it is true that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I cannot, by means of speculative reason, and still less by empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: observation, cognize my soul as a thing in itself and consequently,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I cannot cognize, I can quite well think freedom, that is to say, my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from them. Suppose now that morality necessarily presupposed liberty,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the strictest sense, as a property of our will; suppose that reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: same time, that speculative reason had proved that liberty was

text: opposite of which involves an obvious contradiction, and that liberty

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: That all our knowledge begins with experience there can be no doubt. For
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: into a knowledge of objects, which is called experience? In respect of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time, therefore, no knowledge of ours is antecedent to experience, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: begins with it.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: IV. Of the Difference Between Analytical and Synthetical Judgements.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In all judgements wherein the relation of a subject to the predicate is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitated (I mention affirmative judgements only here; the application
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to negative will be very easy), this relation is possible in two
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: different ways. Either the predicate B belongs to the subject A, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: somewhat which is contained (though covertly) in the conception A; or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the predicate B lies completely out of the conception A, although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it stands in connection with it. In the first instance, I term the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgement analytical, in the second, synthetical. Analytical judgements
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (affirmative) are therefore those in which the connection of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicate with the subject is cogitated through identity; those in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this connection is cogitated without identity, are called synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgements. The former may be called explicative, the latter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: augmentative judgements; because the former add in the predicate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nothing to the conception of the subject, but only analyse it into its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constituent conceptions, which were thought already in the subject,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although in a confused manner; the latter add to our conceptions of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject a predicate which was not contained in it, and which no analysis
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: could ever have discovered therein. For example, when I say, "All bodies
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are extended," this is an analytical judgement. For I need not go beyond
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception of body in order to find extension connected with it, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely analyse the conception, that is, become conscious of the manifold
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: properties which I think in that conception, in order to discover this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicate in it: it is therefore an analytical judgement. On the other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hand, when I say, "All bodies are heavy," the predicate is something
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: totally different from that which I think in the mere conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a body. By the addition of such a predicate, therefore, it becomes a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthetical judgement.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Judgements of experience, as such, are always synthetical. For it would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be absurd to think of grounding an analytical judgement on experience,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: because in forming such a judgement I need not go out of the sphere of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: my conceptions, and therefore recourse to the testimony of experience
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is quite unnecessary. That "bodies are extended" is not an empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgement, but a proposition which stands firm a priori. For before
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: addressing myself to experience, I already have in my conception all the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: requisite conditions for the judgement, and I have only to extract
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the predicate from the conception, according to the principle of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradiction, and thereby at the same time become conscious of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessity of the judgement, a necessity which I could never learn from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience. On the other hand, though at first I do not at all include
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the predicate of weight in my conception of body in general, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception still indicates an object of experience, a part of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: totality of experience, to which I can still add other parts; and this I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: do when I recognize by observation that bodies are heavy. I can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognize beforehand by analysis the conception of body through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: characteristics of extension, impenetrability, shape, etc., all which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are cogitated in this conception. But now I extend my knowledge, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: looking back on experience from which I had derived this conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of body, I find weight at all times connected with the above
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: characteristics, and therefore I synthetically add to my conceptions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this as a predicate, and say, "All bodies are heavy." Thus it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience upon which rests the possibility of the synthesis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the predicate of weight with the conception of body, because both
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, although the one is not contained in the other, still
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belong to one another (only contingently, however), as parts of a whole,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: namely, of experience, which is itself a synthesis of intuitions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But to synthetical judgements a priori, such aid is entirely wanting. If
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I go out of and beyond the conception A, in order to recognize another
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: B as connected with it, what foundation have I to rest on, whereby to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: render the synthesis possible? I have here no longer the advantage of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: looking out in the sphere of experience for what I want. Let us take,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for example, the proposition, "Everything that happens has a cause." In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception of "something that happens," I indeed think an existence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which a certain time antecedes, and from this I can derive analytical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception, and indicates something entirely different from "that which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happens"--something entirely different from that conception, and to

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: recognize the conception of cause although not contained in it, yet as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belonging to it, and even necessarily? what is here the unknown = X,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon which the understanding rests when it believes it has found, out of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception A a foreign predicate B, which it nevertheless considers
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to be connected with it? It cannot be experience, because the principle
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: adduced annexes the two representations, cause and effect, to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completely a priori and from pure conceptions. Upon such synthetical,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is augmentative propositions, depends the whole aim of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculative knowledge a priori; for although analytical judgements are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: 1. Mathematical judgements are always synthetical. Hitherto this fact,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: though incontestably true and very important in its consequences, seems
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complete opposition to all their conjectures. For as it was found that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradiction (which the nature of every apodeictic certainty requires),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: people became persuaded that the fundamental principles of the science
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: also were recognized and admitted in the same way. But the notion is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: fallacious; for although a synthetical proposition can certainly be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only when another synthetical proposition precedes, from which the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: latter is deduced, but never of itself.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Before all, be it observed, that proper mathematical propositions are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assertion to pure mathematics, the very conception of which implies that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it consists of knowledge altogether non-empirical and a priori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: and five contains nothing more than the uniting of both sums into one,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. As to metaphysics, even if we look upon it merely as an attempted
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel
