text: (receptivity) through the mode in which we are affected by objects,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects, is called sensibility. By means of sensibility, therefore,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects are given to us, and it alone furnishes us with intuitions; by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding they are thought, and from it arise conceptions. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an thought must directly, or indirectly, by means of certain signs,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relate ultimately to intuitions; consequently, with us, to sensibility,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: because in no other way can an object be given to us.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The effect of an object upon the faculty of representation, so far as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we are affected by the said object, is sensation. That sort of intuition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which relates to an object by means of sensation is called an empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition. The undetermined object of an empirical intuition is called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon. That which in the phenomenon corresponds to the sensation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I term its matter; but that which effects that the content of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon can be arranged under certain relations, I call its form. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that in which our sensations are merely arranged, and by which they are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: susceptible of assuming a certain form, cannot be itself sensation. It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is, then, the matter of all phenomena that is given to us a posteriori;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the form must lie ready a priori for them in the mind, and consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can be regarded separately from all sensation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I call all representations pure, in the transcendental meaning of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the word, wherein nothing is met with that belongs to sensation. And
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: accordingly we find existing in the mind a priori, the pure form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensuous intuitions in general, in which all the manifold content of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenal world is arranged and viewed under certain relations. This
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure form of sensibility I shall call pure intuition. Thus, if I take
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: away from our representation of a body all that the understanding thinks
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as belonging to it, as substance, force, divisibility, etc., and also
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whatever belongs to sensation, as impenetrability, hardness, colour,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: etc.; yet there is still something left us from this empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition, namely, extension and shape. These belong to pure intuition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which exists a priori in the mind, as a mere form of sensibility, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without any real object of the senses or any sensation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The science of all the principles of sensibility a priori, I call
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental aesthetic.* There must, then, be such a science
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: forming the first part of the transcendental doctrine of elements, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradistinction to that part which contains the principles of pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thought, and which is called transcendental logic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [Footnote: The Germans are the only people who at present
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: use this word to indicate what others call the critique of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: taste. At the foundation of this term lies the disappointed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hope, which the eminent analyst, Baumgarten, conceived, of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subjecting the criticism of the beautiful to principles of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, and so of elevating its rules into a science. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: his endeavours were vain. For the said rules or criteria
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are, in respect to their chief sources, merely empirical,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently never can serve as determinate laws a priori,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by which our judgement in matters of taste is to be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: directed. It is rather our judgement which forms the proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: test as to the correctness of the principles. On this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: account it is advisable to give up the use of the term as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: designating the critique of taste, and to apply it solely to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that doctrine, which is true science--the science of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: laws of sensibility--and thus come nearer to the language
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and the sense of the ancients in their well-known division
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the objects of cognition into aiotheta kai noeta, or to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: share it with speculative philosophy, and employ it partly
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in a transcendental, partly in a psychological
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: signification.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the science of transcendental aesthetic accordingly, we shall first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: isolate sensibility or the sensuous faculty, by separating from it all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is annexed to its perceptions by the conceptions of understanding,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so that nothing be left but empirical intuition. In the next place we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: shall take away from this intuition all that belongs to sensation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so that nothing may remain but pure intuition, and the mere form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena, which is all that the sensibility can afford a priori. From
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this investigation it will be found that there are two pure forms of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensuous intuition, as principles of knowledge a priori, namely, space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and time. To the consideration of these we shall now proceed.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION I. Of Space.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 2. Metaphysical Exposition of this Conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: By means of the external sense (a property of the mind), we represent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to ourselves objects as without us, and these all in space. Herein alone
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are their shape, dimensions, and relations to each other determined
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or determinable. The internal sense, by means of which the mind
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contemplates itself or its internal state, gives, indeed, no intuition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the soul as an object; yet there is nevertheless a determinate form,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: under which alone the contemplation of our internal state is possible,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so that all which relates to the inward determinations of the mind is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: represented in relations of time. Of time we cannot have any external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition, any more than we can have an internal intuition of space.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: What then are time and space? Are they real existences? Or, are they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely relations or determinations of things, such, however, as would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: equally belong to these things in themselves, though they should never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: become objects of intuition; or, are they such as belong only to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: form of intuition, and consequently to the subjective constitution of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the mind, without which these predicates of time and space could not be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: attached to any object? In order to become informed on these points,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we shall first give an exposition of the conception of space. By
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exposition, I mean the clear, though not detailed, representation of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that which belongs to a conception; and an exposition is metaphysical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when it contains that which represents the conception as given a priori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 1. Space is not a conception which has been derived from outward
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experiences. For, in order that certain sensations may relate to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: something without me (that is, to something which occupies a different
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: part of space from that in which I am); in like manner, in order that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I may represent them not merely as without, of, and near to each other,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but also in separate places, the representation of space must already
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exist as a foundation. Consequently, the representation of space cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be borrowed from the relations of external phenomena through experience;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but, on the contrary, this external experience is itself only possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: through the said antecedent representation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. Space then is a necessary representation a priori, which serves for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the foundation of all external intuitions. We never can imagine or make
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a representation to ourselves of the non-existence of space, though
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we may easily enough think that no objects are found in it. It must,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, be considered as the condition of the possibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena, and by no means as a determination dependent on them, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is a representation a priori, which necessarily supplies the basis for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external phenomena.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. Space is no discursive, or as we say, general conception of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relations of things, but a pure intuition. For, in the first place, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can only represent to ourselves one space, and, when we talk of divers
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: spaces, we mean only parts of one and the same space. Moreover, these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts cannot antecede this one all-embracing space, as the component
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts from which the aggregate can be made up, but can be cogitated only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as existing in it. Space is essentially one, and multiplicity in it,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently the general notion of spaces, of this or that space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: depends solely upon limitations. Hence it follows that an a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition (which is not empirical) lies at the root of all our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions of space. Thus, moreover, the principles of geometry--for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: example, that "in a triangle, two sides together are greater than the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: third," are never deduced from general conceptions of line and triangle,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but from intuition, and this a priori, with apodeictic certainty.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 4. Space is represented as an infinite given quantity. Now every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception must indeed be considered as a representation which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is contained in an infinite multitude of different possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, which, therefore, comprises these under itself; but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no conception, as such, can be so conceived, as if it contained within
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself an infinite multitude of representations. Nevertheless, space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is so conceived of, for all parts of space are equally capable of being
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: produced to infinity. Consequently, the original representation of space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is an intuition a priori, and not a conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 3. Transcendental Exposition of the Conception of Space.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: By a transcendental exposition, I mean the explanation of a conception,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as a principle, whence can be discerned the possibility of other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthetical a priori cognitions. For this purpose, it is requisite,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: firstly, that such cognitions do really flow from the given conception;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and, secondly, that the said cognitions are only possible under the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presupposition of a given mode of explaining this conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Geometry is a science which determines the properties of space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthetically, and yet a priori. What, then, must be our representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of space, in order that such a cognition of it may be possible? It must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be originally intuition, for from a mere conception, no propositions can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be deduced which go out beyond the conception, and yet this happens in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: geometry. (Introd. V.) But this intuition must be found in the mind a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori, that is, before any perception of objects, consequently must be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure, not empirical, intuition. For geometrical principles are always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apodeictic, that is, united with the consciousness of their necessity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as: "Space has only three dimensions." But propositions of this kind
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be empirical judgements, nor conclusions from them. (Introd. II.)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, how can an external intuition anterior to objects themselves, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in which our conception of objects can be determined a priori, exist
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the human mind? Obviously not otherwise than in so far as it has its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: seat in the subject only, as the formal capacity of the subject's being
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: affected by objects, and thereby of obtaining immediate representation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, intuition; consequently, only as the form of the external sense
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in general.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thus it is only by means of our explanation that the possibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: geometry, as a synthetical science a priori, becomes comprehensible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Every mode of explanation which does not show us this possibility,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although in appearance it may be similar to ours, can with the utmost
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certainty be distinguished from it by these marks.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 4. Conclusions from the foregoing Conceptions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (a) Space does not represent any property of objects as things in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves, nor does it represent them in their relations to each other;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in other words, space does not represent to us any determination of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects such as attaches to the objects themselves, and would remain,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: even though all subjective conditions of the intuition were abstracted.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For neither absolute nor relative determinations of objects can be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuited prior to the existence of the things to which they belong, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore not a priori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (b) Space is nothing else than the form of all phenomena of the external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sense, that is, the subjective condition of the sensibility, under which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: alone external intuition is possible. Now, because the receptivity or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: capacity of the subject to be affected by objects necessarily antecedes
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all intuitions of these objects, it is easily understood how the form
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all phenomena can be given in the mind previous to all actual
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perceptions, therefore a priori, and how it, as a pure intuition, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which all objects must be determined, can contain principles of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relations of these objects prior to all experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It is therefore from the human point of view only that we can speak
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of space, extended objects, etc. If we depart from the subjective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition, under which alone we can obtain external intuition, or,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in other words, by means of which we are affected by objects, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of space has no meaning whatsoever. This predicate is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only applicable to things in so far as they appear to us, that is, are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects of sensibility. The constant form of this receptivity, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we call sensibility, is a necessary condition of all relations in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects can be intuited as existing without us, and when abstraction of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these objects is made, is a pure intuition, to which we give the name
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of space. It is clear that we cannot make the special conditions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensibility into conditions of the possibility of things, but only of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the possibility of their existence as far as they are phenomena. And
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so we may correctly say that space contains all which can appear to us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: externally, but not all things considered as things in themselves,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be they intuited or not, or by whatsoever subject one will. As to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuitions of other thinking beings, we cannot judge whether they are or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are not bound by the same conditions which limit our own intuition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and which for us are universally valid. If we join the limitation of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a judgement to the conception of the subject, then the judgement will
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possess unconditioned validity. For example, the proposition, "All
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects are beside each other in space," is valid only under the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limitation that these things are taken as objects of our sensuous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition. But if I join the condition to the conception and say, "All
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things, as external phenomena, are beside each other in space," then the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rule is valid universally, and without any limitation. Our expositions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently, teach the reality (i.e., the objective validity) of space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in regard of all which can be presented to us externally as object, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: at the same time also the ideality of space in regard to objects when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: they are considered by means of reason as things in themselves, that is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without reference to the constitution of our sensibility. We maintain,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, the empirical reality of space in regard to all possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external experience, although we must admit its transcendental ideality;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in other words, that it is nothing, so soon as we withdraw the condition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon which the possibility of all experience depends and look upon space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as something that belongs to things in themselves.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But, with the exception of space, there is no representation, subjective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and referring to something external to us, which could be called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objective a priori. For there are no other subjective representations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from which we can deduce synthetical propositions a priori, as we can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the intuition of space. (See SS 3.) Therefore, to speak accurately,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no ideality whatever belongs to these, although they agree in this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: respect with the representation of space, that they belong merely to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subjective nature of the mode of sensuous perception; such a mode, for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: example, as that of sight, of hearing, and of feeling, by means of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensations of colour, sound, and heat, but which, because they are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only sensations and not intuitions, do not of themselves give us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the cognition of any object, least of all, an a priori cognition. My
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: purpose, in the above remark, is merely this: to guard any one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: against illustrating the asserted ideality of space by examples quite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: insufficient, for example, by colour, taste, etc.; for these must be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contemplated not as properties of things, but only as changes in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject, changes which may be different in different men. For, in such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a case, that which is originally a mere phenomenon, a rose, for example,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is taken by the empirical understanding for a thing in itself, though to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every different eye, in respect of its colour, it may appear different.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: On the contrary, the transcendental conception of phenomena in space is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a critical admonition, that, in general, nothing which is intuited in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space is a thing in itself, and that space is not a form which belongs
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as a property to things; but that objects are quite unknown to us in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves, and what we call outward objects, are nothing else but mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations of our sensibility, whose form is space, but whose
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: real correlate, the thing in itself, is not known by means of these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, nor ever can be, but respecting which, in experience,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no inquiry is ever made.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION II. Of Time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 5. Metaphysical Exposition of this Conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 1. Time is not an empirical conception. For neither coexistence nor
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: succession would be perceived by us, if the representation of time did
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not exist as a foundation a priori. Without this presupposition we could
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not represent to ourselves that things exist together at one and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: same time, or at different times, that is, contemporaneously, or in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: succession.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. Time is a necessary representation, lying at the foundation of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our intuitions. With regard to phenomena in general, we cannot think
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: away time from them, and represent them to ourselves as out of and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconnected with time, but we can quite well represent to ourselves time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: void of phenomena. Time is therefore given a priori. In it alone is all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality of phenomena possible. These may all be annihilated in thought,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but time itself, as the universal condition of their possibility, cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be so annulled.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. On this necessity a priori is also founded the possibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apodeictic principles of the relations of time, or axioms of time in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: general, such as: "Time has only one dimension," "Different times are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not coexistent but successive" (as different spaces are not successive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but coexistent). These principles cannot be derived from experience, for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it would give neither strict universality, nor apodeictic certainty. We
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: should only be able to say, "so common experience teaches us," but not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: "it must be so." They are valid as rules, through which, in general,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience is possible; and they instruct us respecting experience, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not by means of it.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 4. Time is not a discursive, or as it is called, general conception, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a pure form of the sensuous intuition. Different times are merely parts
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of one and the same time. But the representation which can only be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given by a single object is an intuition. Besides, the proposition that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: different times cannot be coexistent could not be derived from a general
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception. For this proposition is synthetical, and therefore cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: spring out of conceptions alone. It is therefore contained immediately
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the intuition and representation of time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 5. The infinity of time signifies nothing more than that every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determined quantity of time is possible only through limitations of one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time lying at the foundation. Consequently, the original representation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time, must be given as unlimited. But as the determinate representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the parts of time and of every quantity of an object can only be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: obtained by limitation, the complete representation of time must not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be furnished by means of conceptions, for these contain only partial
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations. Conceptions, on the contrary, must have immediate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition for their basis.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 6 Transcendental Exposition of the Conception of Time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I may here refer to what is said above (SS 5, 3), where, for or sake of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: brevity, I have placed under the head of metaphysical exposition, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is properly transcendental. Here I shall add that the conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of change, and with it the conception of motion, as change of place, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible only through and in the representation of time; that if this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation were not an intuition (internal) a priori, no conception,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of whatever kind, could render comprehensible the possibility of change,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in other words, of a conjunction of contradictorily opposed predicates
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in one and the same object, for example, the presence of a thing in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: place and the non-presence of the same thing in the same place. It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is only in time that it is possible to meet with two contradictorily
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: opposed determinations in one thing, that is, after each other. Thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our conception of time explains the possibility of so much synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: knowledge a priori, as is exhibited in the general doctrine of motion,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is not a little fruitful.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 7. Conclusions from the above Conceptions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (a) Time is not something which subsists of itself, or which inheres
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in things as an objective determination, and therefore remains, when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstraction is made of the subjective conditions of the intuition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things. For in the former case, it would be something real, yet without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presenting to any power of perception any real object. In the latter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: case, as an order or determination inherent in things themselves, it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: could not be antecedent to things, as their condition, nor discerned or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuited by means of synthetical propositions a priori. But all this is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quite possible when we regard time as merely the subjective condition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: under which all our intuitions take place. For in that case, this form
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the inward intuition can be represented prior to the objects, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently a priori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (b) Time is nothing else than the form of the internal sense, that is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the intuitions of self and of our internal state. For time cannot be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any determination of outward phenomena. It has to do neither with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: shape nor position; on the contrary, it determines the relation of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations in our internal state. And precisely because this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: internal intuition presents to us no shape or form, we endeavour to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supply this want by analogies, and represent the course of time by a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: line progressing to infinity, the content of which constitutes a series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is only of one dimension; and we conclude from the properties of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this line as to all the properties of time, with this single exception,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that the parts of the line are coexistent, whilst those of time are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: successive. From this it is clear also that the representation of time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is itself an intuition, because all its relations can be expressed in an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external intuition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (c) Time is the formal condition a priori of all phenomena whatsoever.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Space, as the pure form of external intuition, is limited as a condition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a priori to external phenomena alone. On the other hand, because all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, whether they have or have not external things for their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects, still in themselves, as determinations of the mind, belong to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our internal state; and because this internal state is subject to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: formal condition of the internal intuition, that is, to time--time is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition a priori of all phenomena whatsoever--the immediate condition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all internal, and thereby the mediate condition of all external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena. If I can say a priori, "All outward phenomena are in space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and determined a priori according to the relations of space," I can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: also, from the principle of the internal sense, affirm universally, "All
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena in general, that is, all objects of the senses, are in time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and stand necessarily in relations of time."
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If we abstract our internal intuition of ourselves and all external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuitions, possible only by virtue of this internal intuition and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presented to us by our faculty of representation, and consequently take
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects as they are in themselves, then time is nothing. It is only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of objective validity in regard to phenomena, because these are things
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which we regard as objects of our senses. It no longer objective we,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: make abstraction of the sensuousness of our intuition, in other words,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of that mode of representation which is peculiar to us, and speak of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things in general. Time is therefore merely a subjective condition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our (human) intuition (which is always sensuous, that is, so far as we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are affected by objects), and in itself, independently of the mind
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or subject, is nothing. Nevertheless, in respect of all phenomena,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently of all things which come within the sphere of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, it is necessarily objective. We cannot say, "All things are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in time," because in this conception of things in general, we abstract
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and make no mention of any sort of intuition of things. But this is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the proper condition under which time belongs to our representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of objects. If we add the condition to the conception, and say, "All
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things, as phenomena, that is, objects of sensuous intuition, are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in time," then the proposition has its sound objective validity and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: universality a priori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: What we have now set forth teaches, therefore, the empirical reality of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time; that is, its objective validity in reference to all objects which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can ever be presented to our senses. And as our intuition is always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensuous, no object ever can be presented to us in experience, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: does not come under the conditions of time. On the other hand, we deny
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to time all claim to absolute reality; that is, we deny that it, without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: having regard to the form of our sensuous intuition, absolutely inheres
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in things as a condition or property. Such properties as belong to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects as things in themselves never can be presented to us through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the medium of the senses. Herein consists, therefore, the transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ideality of time, according to which, if we abstract the subjective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions of sensuous intuition, it is nothing, and cannot be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reckoned as subsisting or inhering in objects as things in themselves,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: independently of its relation to our intuition. This ideality, like that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of space, is not to be proved or illustrated by fallacious analogies
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with sensations, for this reason--that in such arguments or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: illustrations, we make the presupposition that the phenomenon, in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: such and such predicates inhere, has objective reality, while in this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: case we can only find such an objective reality as is itself empirical,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, regards the object as a mere phenomenon. In reference to this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject, see the remark in Section I (SS 4)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 8. Elucidation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Against this theory, which grants empirical reality to time, but denies
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to it absolute and transcendental reality, I have heard from intelligent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: men an objection so unanimously urged that I conclude that it must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: naturally present itself to every reader to whom these considerations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are novel. It runs thus: "Changes are real" (this the continual change
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in our own representations demonstrates, even though the existence of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all external phenomena, together with their changes, is denied). Now,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: changes are only possible in time, and therefore time must be something
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: real. But there is no difficulty in answering this. I grant the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: argument. Time, no doubt, is something real, that is, it is the real
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: form of our internal intuition. It therefore has subjective reality,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in reference to our internal experience, that is, I have really
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the representation of time and of my determinations therein. Time,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, is not to be regarded as an object, but as the mode of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of myself as an object. But if I could intuite myself,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or be intuited by another being, without this condition of sensibility,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: then those very determinations which we now represent to ourselves as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: changes, would present to us a knowledge in which the representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of time, and consequently of change, would not appear. The empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality of time, therefore, remains, as the condition of all our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience. But absolute reality, according to what has been said above,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be granted it. Time is nothing but the form of our internal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition.* If we take away from it the special condition of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensibility, the conception of time also vanishes; and it inheres not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the objects themselves, but solely in the subject (or mind) which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuites them.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: I can indeed say "my representations follow one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: another, or are successive"; but this means only that we are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conscious of them as in a succession, that is, according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the form of the internal sense. Time, therefore, is not a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thing in itself, nor is it any objective determination
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pertaining to, or inherent in things.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But the reason why this objection is so unanimously brought against
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our doctrine of time, and that too by disputants who cannot start any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intelligible arguments against the doctrine of the ideality of space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is this--they have no hope of demonstrating apodeictically the absolute
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality of space, because the doctrine of idealism is against them,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to which the reality of external objects is not capable of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any strict proof. On the other hand, the reality of the object of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our internal sense (that is, myself and my internal state) is clear
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immediately through consciousness. The former--external objects in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space--might be a mere delusion, but the latter--the object of my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: internal perception--is undeniably real. They do not, however, reflect
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that both, without question of their reality as representations, belong
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only to the genus phenomenon, which has always two aspects, the one, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object considered as a thing in itself, without regard to the mode
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of intuiting it, and the nature of which remains for this very reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: problematical, the other, the form of our intuition of the object,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which must be sought not in the object as a thing in itself, but in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the subject to which it appears--which form of intuition nevertheless
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belongs really and necessarily to the phenomenal object.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Time and space are, therefore, two sources of knowledge, from which, a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori, various synthetical cognitions can be drawn. Of this we find
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a striking example in the cognitions of space and its relations, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: form the foundation of pure mathematics. They are the two pure forms
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all intuitions, and thereby make synthetical propositions a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible. But these sources of knowledge being merely conditions of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensibility, do therefore, and as such, strictly determine their own
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: range and purpose, in that they do not and cannot present objects as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things in themselves, but are applicable to them solely in so far as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: they are considered as sensuous phenomena. The sphere of phenomena is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the only sphere of their validity, and if we venture out of this, no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: further objective use can be made of them. For the rest, this formal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality of time and space leaves the validity of our empirical knowledge
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unshaken; for our certainty in that respect is equally firm, whether
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these forms necessarily inhere in the things themselves, or only in our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuitions of them. On the other hand, those who maintain the absolute
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality of time and space, whether as essentially subsisting, or only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inhering, as modifications, in things, must find themselves at utter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: variance with the principles of experience itself. For, if they decide
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for the first view, and make space and time into substances, this being
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the side taken by mathematical natural philosophers, they must admit
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: two self-subsisting nonentities, infinite and eternal, which exist (yet
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: III. When we say that the intuition of external objects, and also the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-intuition of the subject, represent both, objects and subject, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space and time, as they affect our senses, that is, as they appear--this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is by no means equivalent to asserting that these objects are mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: illusory appearances. For when we speak of things as phenomena, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects, nay, even the properties which we ascribe to them, are looked
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon as really given; only that, in so far as this or that property
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: depends upon the mode of intuition of the subject, in the relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the given object to the subject, the object as phenomenon is to be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguished from the object as a thing in itself. Thus I do not say
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that bodies seem or appear to be external to me, or that my soul seems
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely to be given in my self-consciousness, although I maintain that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the properties of space and time, in conformity to which I set both, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the condition of their existence, abide in my mode of intuition, and not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the objects in themselves. It would be my own fault, if out of that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which I should reckon as phenomenon, I made mere illusory appearance.*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But this will not happen, because of our principle of the ideality
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all sensuous intuitions. On the contrary, if we ascribe objective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality to these forms of representation, it becomes impossible to avoid
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: changing everything into mere appearance. For if we regard space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and time as properties, which must be found in objects as things in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves, as sine quibus non of the possibility of their existence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and reflect on the absurdities in which we then find ourselves involved,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inasmuch as we are compelled to admit the existence of two infinite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things, which are nevertheless not substances, nor anything really
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inhering in substances, nay, to admit that they are the necessary
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions of the existence of all things, and moreover, that they must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: continue to exist, although all existing things were annihilated--we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot blame the good Berkeley for degrading bodies to mere illusory
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: appearances. Nay, even our own existence, which would in this case
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: depend upon the self-existent reality of such a mere nonentity as time,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: would necessarily be changed with it into mere appearance--an absurdity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which no one has as yet been guilty of.

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: IV. In natural theology, where we think of an object--God--which never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: general, space and time must be conditions of the existence of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by the object.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: SS 10. Conclusion of the Transcendental Aesthetic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We have now completely before us one part of the solution of the grand
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: general problem of transcendental philosophy, namely, the question: "How
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are synthetical propositions a priori possible?" That is to say, we have
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: shown that we are in possession of pure a priori intuitions, namely,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space and time, in which we find, when in a judgement a priori we pass
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: out beyond the given conception, something which is not discoverable in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that conception, but is certainly found a priori in the intuition which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: corresponds to the conception, and can be united synthetically with it.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But the judgements which these pure intuitions enable us to make, never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reach farther than to objects of the senses, and are valid only for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects of possible experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECOND PART. TRANSCENDENTAL LOGIC.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: INTRODUCTION. Idea of a Transcendental Logic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I. Of Logic in General.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Our knowledge springs from two main sources in the mind, first of which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is the faculty or power of receiving representations (receptivity for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impressions); the second is the power of cognizing by means of these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations (spontaneity in the production of conceptions). Through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the first an object is given to us; through the second, it is, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to the representation (which is a mere determination of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mind), thought. Intuition and conceptions constitute, therefore, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: elements of all our knowledge, so that neither conceptions without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an intuition in some way corresponding to them, nor intuition without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, can afford us a cognition. Both are either pure or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical. They are empirical, when sensation (which presupposes the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: actual presence of the object) is contained in them; and pure, when no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensation is mixed with the representation. Sensations we may call
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the matter of sensuous cognition. Pure intuition consequently contains
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely the form under which something is intuited, and pure conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only the form of the thought of an object. Only pure intuitions and pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions are possible a priori; the empirical only a posteriori.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We apply the term sensibility to the receptivity of the mind for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impressions, in so far as it is in some way affected; and, on the other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hand, we call the faculty of spontaneously producing representations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or the spontaneity of cognition, understanding. Our nature is so
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constituted that intuition with us never can be other than sensuous,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, it contains only the mode in which we are affected by objects.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: On the other hand, the faculty of thinking the object of sensuous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition is the understanding. Neither of these faculties has a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: preference over the other. Without the sensuous faculty no object
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: would be given to us, and without the understanding no object would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be thought. Thoughts without content are void; intuitions without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, blind. Hence it is as necessary for the mind to make its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions sensuous (that is, to join to them the object in intuition),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as to make its intuitions intelligible (that is, to bring them under
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions). Neither of these faculties can exchange its proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: function. Understanding cannot intuite, and the sensuous faculty cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: think. In no other way than from the united operation of both, can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: knowledge arise. But no one ought, on this account, to overlook the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: difference of the elements contributed by each; we have rather great
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason carefully to separate and distinguish them. We therefore
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguish the science of the laws of sensibility, that is, aesthetic,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the science of the laws of the understanding, that is, logic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, logic in its turn may be considered as twofold--namely, as logic
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the general, or of the particular use of the understanding. The first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contains the absolutely necessary laws of thought, without which no use
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whatsoever of the understanding is possible, and gives laws therefore to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding, without regard to the difference of objects on which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it may be employed. The logic of the particular use of the understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contains the laws of correct thinking upon a particular class of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objects. The former may be called elemental logic--the latter, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: organon of this or that particular science. The latter is for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: most part employed in the schools, as a propaedeutic to the sciences,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although, indeed, according to the course of human reason, it is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: General logic is again either pure or applied. In the former, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstract all the empirical conditions under which the understanding is

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: When we call into play a faculty of cognition, different conceptions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: manifest themselves according to the different circumstances, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: make known this faculty, and assemble themselves into a more or less
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extensive collection, according to the time or penetration that has been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: applied to the consideration of them. Where this process, conducted as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is mechanically, so to speak, will end, cannot be determined with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certainty. Besides, the conceptions which we discover in this haphazard
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: manner present themselves by no means in order and systematic unity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but are at last coupled together only according to resemblances to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other, and arranged in series, according to the quantity of their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content, from the simpler to the more complex--series which are anything
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but systematic, though not altogether without a certain kind of method
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in their construction.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental philosophy has the advantage, and moreover the duty, of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: searching for its conceptions according to a principle; because these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions spring pure and unmixed out of the understanding as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an absolute unity, and therefore must be connected with each other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to one conception or idea. A connection of this kind, however,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: furnishes us with a ready prepared rule, by which its proper place
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may be assigned to every pure conception of the understanding, and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completeness of the system of all be determined a priori--both which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
