text: SS 4. SECTION 1. Of defined above Use of understanding in General.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The understanding was defined above only negatively, as a non-sensuous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: faculty of cognition. Now, independently of sensibility, we cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibly have any intuition; consequently, the understanding is no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: faculty of intuition. But besides intuition there is no other mode of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition, except through conceptions; consequently, the cognition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every, at least of every human, understanding is a cognition through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions--not intuitive, but discursive. All intuitions, as sensuous,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: depend on affections; conceptions, therefore, upon functions. By the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: word function I understand the unity of the act of arranging diverse
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations under one common representation. Conceptions, then, are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: based on the spontaneity of thought, as sensuous intuitions are on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: receptivity of impressions. Now, the understanding cannot make any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other use of these conceptions than to judge by means of them. As no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation, except an intuition, relates immediately to its object,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a conception never relates immediately to an object, but only to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: some other representation thereof, be that an intuition or itself a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception. A judgement, therefore, is the mediate cognition of an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object, consequently the representation of a representation of it. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every judgement there is a conception which applies to, and is valid for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: many other conceptions, and which among these comprehends also a given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation, this last being immediately connected with an object.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For example, in the judgement--"All bodies are divisible," our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of divisible applies to various other conceptions; among
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these, however, it is here particularly applied to the conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: body, and this conception of body relates to certain phenomena which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: occur to us. These objects, therefore, are mediately represented by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of divisibility. All judgements, accordingly, are functions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of unity in our representations, inasmuch as, instead of an immediate, a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: higher representation, which comprises this and various others, is used
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for our cognition of the object, and thereby many possible cognitions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are collected into one. But we can reduce all acts of the understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to judgements, so that understanding may be represented as the faculty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of judging. For it is, according to what has been said above, a faculty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of thought. Now thought is cognition by means of conceptions. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, as predicates of possible judgements, relate to some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of a yet undetermined object. Thus the conception of body
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indicates something--for example, metal--which can be cognized by means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of that conception. It is therefore a conception, for the reason alone
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that other representations are contained under it, by means of which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it can relate to objects. It is therefore the predicate to a possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgement; for example: "Every metal is a body." All the functions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding therefore can be discovered, when we can completely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exhibit the functions of unity in judgements. And that this may be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: effected very easily, the following section will show.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: momenta. These may be conveniently represented in the following table:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: from the usual technique of logicians, the following observations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for the prevention of otherwise possible misunderstanding, will not be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without their use.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: 1. Logicians say, with justice, that in the use of judgements in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: syllogisms, singular judgements may be treated like universal ones.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, precisely because a singular judgement has no extent at all, its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicate cannot refer to a part of that which is contained in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the subject and be excluded from the rest. The predicate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is valid for the whole conception just as if it were a general
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception, and had extent, to the whole of which the predicate applied.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: On the other hand, let us compare a singular with a general judgement,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely as a cognition, in regard to quantity. The singular judgement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relates to the general one, as unity to infinity, and is therefore in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself essentially different. Thus, if we estimate a singular judgement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (judicium singulare) not merely according to its intrinsic validity as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgement, but also as a cognition generally, according to its quantity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in comparison with that of other cognitions, it is then entirely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: different from a general judgement (judicium commune), and in a complete
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: table of the momenta of thought deserves a separate place--though,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indeed, this would not be necessary in a logic limited merely to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consideration of the use of judgements in reference to each other.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. In like manner, in transcendental logic, infinite must be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguished from affirmative judgements, although in general logic
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: they are rightly enough classed under affirmative. General logic
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstracts all content of the predicate (though it be negative), and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only considers whether the said predicate be affirmed or denied of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject. But transcendental logic considers also the worth or content of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this logical affirmation--an affirmation by means of a merely negative
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicate, and inquires how much the sum total of our cognition gains
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by this affirmation. For example, if I say of the soul, "It is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mortal"--by this negative judgement I should at least ward off error.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, by the proposition, "The soul is not mortal," I have, in respect of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the logical form, really affirmed, inasmuch as I thereby place the soul
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the unlimited sphere of immortal beings. Now, because of the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sphere of possible existences, the mortal occupies one part, and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immortal the other, neither more nor less is affirmed by the proposition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: than that the soul is one among the infinite multitude of things
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which remain over, when I take away the whole mortal part. But by this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proceeding we accomplish only this much, that the infinite sphere of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all possible existences is in so far limited that the mortal is excluded
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from it, and the soul is placed in the remaining part of the extent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this sphere. But this part remains, notwithstanding this exception,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite, and more and more parts may be taken away from the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sphere, without in the slightest degree thereby augmenting or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: affirmatively determining our conception of the soul. These judgements,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, infinite in respect of their logical extent, are, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: respect of the content of their cognition, merely limitative; and are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently entitled to a place in our transcendental table of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the momenta of thought in judgements, because the function of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding exercised by them may perhaps be of importance in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: field of its pure a priori cognition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. All relations of thought in judgements are those (a) of the predicate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to the subject; (b) of the principle to its consequence; (c) of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: divided cognition and all the members of the division to each other. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the first of these three classes, we consider only two conceptions; in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the second, two judgements; in the third, several judgements in relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to each other. The hypothetical proposition, "If perfect justice exists,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the obstinately wicked are punished," contains properly the relation to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other of two propositions, namely, "Perfect justice exists," and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: "The obstinately wicked are punished." Whether these propositions are in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves true is a question not here decided. Nothing is cogitated
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by means of this judgement except a certain consequence. Finally, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: disjunctive judgement contains a relation of two or more propositions to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other--a relation not of consequence, but of logical opposition, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so far as the sphere of the one proposition excludes that of the other.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But it contains at the same time a relation of community, in so far as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all the propositions taken together fill up the sphere of the cognition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The disjunctive judgement contains, therefore, the relation of the parts
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the whole sphere of a cognition, since the sphere of each part is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complemental part of the sphere of the other, each contributing to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: form the sum total of the divided cognition. Take, for example, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition, "The world exists either through blind chance, or through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: internal necessity, or through an external cause." Each of these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: propositions embraces a part of the sphere of our possible cognition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as to the existence of a world; all of them taken together, the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sphere. To take the cognition out of one of these spheres, is equivalent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to placing it in one of the others; and, on the other hand, to place
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it in one sphere is equivalent to taking it out of the rest. There is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, in a disjunctive judgement a certain community of cognitions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which consists in this, that they mutually exclude each other, yet
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thereby determine, as a whole, the true cognition, inasmuch as, taken
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: together, they make up the complete content of a particular given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition. And this is all that I find necessary, for the sake of what
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: follows, to remark in this place.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 4. The modality of judgements is a quite peculiar function, with this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguishing characteristic, that it contributes nothing to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content of a judgement (for besides quantity, quality, and relation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there is nothing more that constitutes the content of a judgement), but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: concerns itself only with the value of the copula in relation to thought
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in general. Problematical judgements are those in which the affirmation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or negation is accepted as merely possible (ad libitum). In the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assertorical, we regard the proposition as real (true); in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apodeictical, we look on it as necessary.* Thus the two judgements
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (antecedens et consequens), the relation of which constitutes a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hypothetical judgement, likewise those (the members of the division) in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whose reciprocity the disjunctive consists, are only problematical. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the example above given the proposition, "There exists perfect justice,"
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is not stated assertorically, but as an ad libitum judgement, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: someone may choose to adopt, and the consequence alone is assertorical.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Hence such judgements may be obviously false, and yet, taken
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: problematically, be conditions of our cognition of the truth. Thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the proposition, "The world exists only by blind chance," is in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: disjunctive judgement of problematical import only: that is to say, one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may accept it for the moment, and it helps us (like the indication of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the wrong road among all the roads that one can take) to find out the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: true proposition. The problematical proposition is, therefore, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which expresses only logical possibility (which is not objective);
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, it expresses a free choice to admit the validity of such a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition--a merely arbitrary reception of it into the understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The assertorical speaks of logical reality or truth; as, for example,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in a hypothetical syllogism, the antecedens presents itself in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: problematical form in the major, in an assertorical form in the minor,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and it shows that the proposition is in harmony with the laws of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding. The apodeictical proposition cogitates the assertorical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as determined by these very laws of the understanding, consequently as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: affirming a priori, and in this manner it expresses logical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessity. Now because all is here gradually incorporated with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding--inasmuch as in the first place we judge problematically;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: then accept assertorically our judgement as true; lastly, affirm it as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inseparably united with the understanding, that is, as necessary and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apodeictical--we may safely reckon these three functions of modality as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so many momenta of thought.

text: SS 6. SECTION III. Of the Pure Conceptions of the Understanding, or                   Categories.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: General logic, as has been repeatedly said, makes abstraction of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content of cognition, and expects to receive representations from some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other quarter, in order, by means of analysis, to convert them into
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions. On the contrary, transcendental logic has lying before
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it the manifold content of a priori sensibility, which transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: aesthetic presents to it in order to give matter to the pure conceptions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the understanding, without which transcendental logic would have no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content, and be therefore utterly void. Now space and time contain an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite diversity of determinations of pure a priori intuition, but are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nevertheless the condition of the mind's receptivity, under which alone
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it can obtain representations of objects, and which, consequently, must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always affect the conception of these objects. But the spontaneity of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thought requires that this diversity be examined after a certain manner,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: received into the mind, and connected, in order afterwards to form a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition out of it. This Process I call synthesis.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: By the word synthesis, in its most general signification, I understand
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the process of joining different representations to each other and of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: comprehending their diversity in one cognition. This synthesis is pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when the diversity is not given empirically but a priori (as that in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space and time). Our representations must be given previously to any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analysis of them; and no conceptions can arise, quoad their content,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analytically. But the synthesis of a diversity (be it given a priori or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirically) is the first requisite for the production of a cognition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which in its beginning, indeed, may be crude and confused, and therefore
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in need of analysis--still, synthesis is that by which alone the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: elements of our cognitions are collected and united into a certain
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content, consequently it is the first thing on which we must fix our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: attention, if we wish to investigate the origin of our knowledge.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Synthesis, generally speaking, is, as we shall afterwards see, the mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: operation of the imagination--a blind but indispensable function of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: soul, without which we should have no cognition whatever, but of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: working of which we are seldom even conscious. But to reduce this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis to conceptions is a function of the understanding, by means of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which we attain to cognition, in the proper meaning of the term.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Pure synthesis, represented generally, gives us the pure conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding. But by this pure synthesis, I mean that which rests
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon a basis of a priori synthetical unity. Thus, our numeration (and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this is more observable in large numbers) is a synthesis according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, because it takes place according to a common basis of unity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (for example, the decade). By means of this conception, therefore, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity in the synthesis of the manifold becomes necessary.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: By means of analysis different representations are brought under one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception--an operation of which general logic treats. On the other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hand, the duty of transcendental logic is to reduce to conceptions, not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, but the pure synthesis of representations. The first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thing which must be given to us for the sake of the a priori cognition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all objects, is the diversity of the pure intuition; the synthesis
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this diversity by means of the imagination is the second; but this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: gives, as yet, no cognition. The conceptions which give unity to this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure synthesis, and which consist solely in the representation of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this necessary synthetical unity, furnish the third requisite for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the cognition of an object, and these conceptions are given by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The same function which gives unity to the different representation in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a judgement, gives also unity to the mere synthesis of different
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations in an intuition; and this unity we call the pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the understanding. Thus, the same understanding, and by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the same operations, whereby in conceptions, by means of analytical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity, it produced the logical form of a judgement, introduces, by means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the synthetical unity of the manifold in intuition, a transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: content into its representations, on which account they are called pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions of the understanding, and they apply a priori to objects, a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: result not within the power of general logic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In this manner, there arise exactly so many pure conceptions of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding, applying a priori to objects of intuition in general, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there are logical functions in all possible judgements. For there is no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other function or faculty existing in the understanding besides those
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: enumerated in that table. These conceptions we shall, with Aristotle,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: call categories, our purpose being originally identical with his,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: notwithstanding the great difference in the execution.

text: This, then, is a catalogue of all the originally pure conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the synthesis which the understanding contains a priori, and these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions alone entitle it to be called a pure understanding; inasmuch
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as only by them it can render the manifold of intuition conceivable,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in other words, think an object of intuition. This division is made
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: systematically from a common principle, namely the faculty of judgement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (which is just the same as the power of thought), and has not arisen
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rhapsodically from a search at haphazard after pure conceptions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: respecting the full number of which we never could be certain, inasmuch
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as we employ induction alone in our search, without considering that in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this way we can never understand wherefore precisely these conceptions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and none others, abide in the pure understanding. It was a design worthy
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of an acute thinker like Aristotle, to search for these fundamental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions. Destitute, however, of any guiding principle, he picked
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them up just as they occurred to him, and at first hunted out ten, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: he called categories (predicaments). Afterwards be believed that he
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: had discovered five others, which were added under the name of post
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicaments. But his catalogue still remained defective. Besides,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there are to be found among them some of the modes of pure sensibility
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (quando, ubi, situs, also prius, simul), and likewise an empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception (motus)--which can by no means belong to this genealogical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: register of the pure understanding. Moreover, there are deduced
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions (actio, passio) enumerated among the original conceptions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and, of the latter, some are entirely wanting.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: With regard to these, it is to be remarked, that the categories, as the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: true primitive conceptions of the pure understanding, have also their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure deduced conceptions, which, in a complete system of transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophy, must by no means be passed over; though in a merely critical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: essay we must be contented with the simple mention of the fact.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Let it be allowed me to call these pure, but deduced conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding, the predicables of the pure understanding, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradistinction to predicaments. If we are in possession of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: original and primitive, the deduced and subsidiary conceptions can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: easily be added, and the genealogical tree of the understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completely delineated. As my present aim is not to set forth a complete
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: system, but merely the principles of one, I reserve this task for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: another time. It may be easily executed by any one who will refer to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ontological manuals, and subordinate to the category of causality,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for example, the predicables of force, action, passion; to that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: community, those of presence and resistance; to the categories of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: modality, those of origination, extinction, change; and so with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rest. The categories combined with the modes of pure sensibility, or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with one another, afford a great number of deduced a priori conceptions;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a complete enumeration of which would be a useful and not unpleasant,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but in this place a perfectly dispensable, occupation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I purposely omit the definitions of the categories in this treatise.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I shall analyse these conceptions only so far as is necessary for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: doctrine of method, which is to form a part of this critique. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a system of pure reason, definitions of them would be with justice
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: demanded of me, but to give them here would only bide from our view
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the main aim of our investigation, at the same time raising doubts and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: objections, the consideration of which, without injustice to our main
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: purpose, may be very well postponed till another opportunity. Meanwhile,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it ought to be sufficiently clear, from the little we have already said
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: on this subject, that the formation of a complete vocabulary of pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions, accompanied by all the requisite explanations, is not only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a possible, but an easy undertaking. The compartments already exist;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is only necessary to fill them up; and a systematic topic like the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: present, indicates with perfect precision the proper place to which each
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception belongs, while it readily points out any that have not yet
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: been filled up.

text: SS 7.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Our table of the categories suggests considerations of some importance,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which may perhaps have significant results in regard to the scientific
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: form of all rational cognitions. For, that this table is useful in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: theoretical part of philosophy, nay, indispensable for the sketching
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the complete plan of a science, so far as that science rests upon
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions a priori, and for dividing it mathematically, according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: fixed principles, is most manifest from the fact that it contains all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the elementary conceptions of the understanding, nay, even the form of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: system of these in the understanding itself, and consequently indicates
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all the momenta, and also the internal arrangement of a projected
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculative science, as I have elsewhere shown. [Footnote: In the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Metaphysical Principles of Natural Science.] Here follow some of these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: observations.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I. This table, which contains four classes of conceptions of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding, may, in the first instance, be divided into two classes,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the first of which relates to objects of intuition--pure as well as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical; the second, to the existence of these objects, either in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to one another, or to the understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The former of these classes of categories I would entitle the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematical, and the latter the dynamical categories. The former, as we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: see, has no correlates; these are only to be found in the second
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: class. This difference must have a ground in the nature of the human
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: II. The number of the categories in each class is always the same,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: namely, three--a fact which also demands some consideration, because
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in all other cases division a priori through conceptions is necessarily
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: dichotomy. It is to be added, that the third category in each triad
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always arises from the combination of the second with the first.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thus totality is nothing else but plurality contemplated as unity;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limitation is merely reality conjoined with negation; community is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: causality of a substance, reciprocally determining, and determined by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other substances; and finally, necessity is nothing but existence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is given through the possibility itself. Let it not be supposed,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: however, that the third category is merely a deduced, and not a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: primitive conception of the pure understanding. For the conjunction of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the first and second, in order to produce the third conception, requires
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a particular function of the understanding, which is by no means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: identical with those which are exercised in the first and second. Thus,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception of a number (which belongs to the category of totality)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is not always possible, where the conceptions of multitude and unity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exist (for example, in the representation of the infinite). Or, if I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjoin the conception of a cause with that of a substance, it does not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: follow that the conception of influence, that is, how one substance can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be the cause of something in another substance, will be understood from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that. Thus it is evident that a particular act of the understanding is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: here necessary; and so in the other instances.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: III. With respect to one category, namely, that of community, which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: found in the third class, it is not so easy as with the others to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: detect its accordance with the form of the disjunctive judgement which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: corresponds to it in the table of the logical functions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In order to assure ourselves of this accordance, we must observe that in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every disjunctive judgement, the sphere of the judgement (that is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the complex of all that is contained in it) is represented as a whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: divided into parts; and, since one part cannot be contained in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other, they are cogitated as co-ordinated with, not subordinated to each
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other, so that they do not determine each other unilaterally, as in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: linear series, but reciprocally, as in an aggregate--(if one member of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the division is posited, all the rest are excluded; and conversely).
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now a like connection is cogitated in a whole of things; for one thing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is not subordinated, as effect, to another as cause of its existence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but, on the contrary, is co-ordinated contemporaneously and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reciprocally, as a cause in relation to the determination of the others
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (for example, in a body--the parts of which mutually attract and repel
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other). And this is an entirely different kind of connection from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that which we find in the mere relation of the cause to the effect (the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle to the consequence), for in such a connection the consequence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: does not in its turn determine the principle, and therefore does not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constitute, with the latter, a whole--just as the Creator does not with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world make up a whole. The process of understanding by which it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: represents to itself the sphere of a divided conception, is employed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: also when we think of a thing as divisible; and in the same manner as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the members of the division in the former exclude one another, and yet
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are connected in one sphere, so the understanding represents to itself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the parts of the latter, as having--each of them--an existence (as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substances), independently of the others, and yet as united in one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whole.

text: SS 8.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the transcendental philosophy of the ancients there exists one more
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: leading division, which contains pure conceptions of the understanding,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and which, although not numbered among the categories, ought, according
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to them, as conceptions a priori, to be valid of objects. But in this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: case they would augment the number of the categories; which cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be. These are set forth in the proposition, so renowned among the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: schoolmen--"Quodlibet ens est UNUM, VERUM, BONUM." Now, though the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inferences from this principle were mere tautological propositions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and though it is allowed only by courtesy to retain a place in modern
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: metaphysics, yet a thought which maintained itself for such a length
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of time, however empty it seems to be, deserves an investigation of its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: origin, and justifies the conjecture that it must be grounded in some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: law of the understanding, which, as is often the case, has only been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: erroneously interpreted. These pretended transcendental predicates are,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in fact, nothing but logical requisites and criteria of all cognition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of objects, and they employ, as the basis for this cognition, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: categories of quantity, namely, unity, plurality, and totality. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these, which must be taken as material conditions, that is, as belonging
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to the possibility of things themselves, they employed merely in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: formal signification, as belonging to the logical requisites of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition, and yet most unguardedly changed these criteria of thought
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: into properties of objects, as things in themselves. Now, in every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition of an object, there is unity of conception, which may be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: called qualitative unity, so far as by this term we understand only the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity in our connection of the manifold; for example, unity of the theme
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in a play, an oration, or a story. Secondly, there is truth in respect

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: met with is not deduction, but only an illustration of them, because

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: yet leave open for her the entire sphere of her legitimate activity.

text: I shall merely premise an explanation of what the categories are. They
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are conceptions of an object in general, by means of which its intuition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is contemplated as determined in relation to one of the logical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: functions of judgement. The following will make this plain. The function
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the categorical judgement is that of the relation of subject to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicate; for example, in the proposition: "All bodies are divisible."
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But in regard to the merely logical use of the understanding, it still
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: function Of subject and to which that of predicate. For we could also
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: say: "Some divisible is a body." But the category of substance, when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception of a body is brought under it, determines that; and its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical intuition in experience must be contemplated always as subject
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and never as mere predicate. And so with all the other categories.

text: SS 11. SECTION II Transcendental Deduction of the pure Conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the Understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Of the Possibility of a Conjunction of the manifold representations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given by Sense.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The manifold content in our representations can be given in an intuition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is merely sensuous--in other words, is nothing but susceptibility;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and the form of this intuition can exist a priori in our faculty of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation, without being anything else but the mode in which the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject is affected. But the conjunction (conjunctio) of a manifold in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition never can be given us by the senses; it cannot therefore
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be contained in the pure form of sensuous intuition, for it is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: spontaneous act of the faculty of representation. And as we must, to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguish it from sensibility, entitle this faculty understanding; so
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all conjunction whether conscious or unconscious, be it of the manifold
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in intuition, sensuous or non-sensuous, or of several conceptions--is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an act of the understanding. To this act we shall give the general
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: appellation of synthesis, thereby to indicate, at the same time, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we cannot represent anything as conjoined in the object without having
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: previously conjoined it ourselves. Of all mental notions, that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjunction is the only one which cannot be given through objects, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can be originated only by the subject itself, because it is an act of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its purely spontaneous activity. The reader will easily enough perceive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that the possibility of conjunction must be grounded in the very nature
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this act, and that it must be equally valid for all conjunction, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that analysis, which appears to be its contrary, must, nevertheless,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always presuppose it; for where the understanding has not previously
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjoined, it cannot dissect or analyse, because only as conjoined by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it, must that which is to be analysed have been given to our faculty of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But the conception of conjunction includes, besides the conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the manifold and of the synthesis of it, that of the unity of it also.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Conjunction is the representation of the synthetical unity of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: manifold.* This idea of unity, therefore, cannot arise out of that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjunction; much rather does that idea, by combining itself with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of the manifold, render the conception of conjunction
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible. This unity, which a priori precedes all conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjunction, is not the category of unity (SS 6); for all the categories
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are based upon logical functions of judgement, and in these functions we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: already have conjunction, and consequently unity of given conceptions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It is therefore evident that the category of unity presupposes
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjunction. We must therefore look still higher for this unity (as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: qualitative, SS 8), in that, namely, which contains the ground of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity of diverse conceptions in judgements, the ground, consequently, of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the possibility of the existence of the understanding, even in regard to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its logical use.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: Whether the representations are in themselves
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: identical, and consequently whether one can be thought
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analytically by means of and through the other, is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: question which we need not at present consider. Our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Consciousness of the one, when we speak of the manifold, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always distinguishable from our consciousness of the other;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and it is only respecting the synthesis of this (possible)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consciousness that we here treat.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SS 12. Of the Originally Synthetical Unity of Apperception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The "I think" must accompany all my representations, for otherwise
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: something would be represented in me which could not be thought; in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other words, the representation would either be impossible, or at least
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be, in relation to me, nothing. That representation which can be given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: previously to all thought is called intuition. All the diversity or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: manifold content of intuition, has, therefore, a necessary relation to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the "I think," in the subject in which this diversity is found. But this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation, "I think," is an act of spontaneity; that is to say,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it cannot be regarded as belonging to mere sensibility. I call it pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apperception, in order to distinguish it from empirical; or primitive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apperception, because it is self-consciousness which, whilst it gives
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: birth to the representation "I think," must necessarily be capable of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: accompanying all our representations. It is in all acts of consciousness
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one and the same, and unaccompanied by it, no representation can exist
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for me. The unity of this apperception I call the transcendental unity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of self-consciousness, in order to indicate the possibility of a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition arising from it. For the manifold representations which are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given in an intuition would not all of them be my representations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: if they did not all belong to one self-consciousness, that is, as my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations (even although I am not conscious of them as such), they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must conform to the condition under which alone they can exist together
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in a common self-consciousness, because otherwise they would not all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without exception belong to me. From this primitive conjunction follow
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: many important results.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For example, this universal identity of the apperception of the manifold
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given in intuition contains a synthesis of representations and is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible only by means of the consciousness of this synthesis. For the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical consciousness which accompanies different representations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is in itself fragmentary and disunited, and without relation to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: identity of the subject. This relation, then, does not exist because I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: accompany every representation with consciousness, but because I join
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one representation to another, and am conscious of the synthesis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them. Consequently, only because I can connect a variety of given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations in one consciousness, is it possible that I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can represent to myself the identity of consciousness in these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations; in other words, the analytical unity of apperception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is possible only under the presupposition of a synthetical unity.* The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thought, "These representations given in intuition belong all of them
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to me," is accordingly just the same as, "I unite them in one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-consciousness, or can at least so unite them"; and although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this thought is not itself the consciousness of the synthesis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, it presupposes the possibility of it; that is to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: say, for the reason alone that I can comprehend the variety of my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations in one consciousness, do I call them my representations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for otherwise I must have as many-coloured and various a self as are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the representations of which I am conscious. Synthetical unity of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: manifold in intuitions, as given a priori, is therefore the foundation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the identity of apperception itself, which antecedes a priori all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determinate thought. But the conjunction of representations into a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception is not to be found in objects themselves, nor can it be,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as it were, borrowed from them and taken up into the understanding by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perception, but it is on the contrary an operation of the understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself, which is nothing more than the faculty of conjoining a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and of bringing the variety of given representations under the unity of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apperception. This principle is the highest in all human cognition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: All general conceptions--as such--depend, for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: their existence, on the analytical unity of consciousness.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations; consequently, it is only by means of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: forethought possible synthetical unity that I can think to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: myself the analytical. A representation which is cogitated
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as common to different representations, is regarded as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belonging to such as, besides this common representation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contain something different; consequently it must be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: previously thought in synthetical unity with other although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only possible representations, before I can think in it the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analytical unity of consciousness which makes it a conceptas
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: communis. And thus the synthetical unity of apperception is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the highest point with which we must connect every operation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the understanding, even the whole of logic, and after it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our transcendental philosophy; indeed, this faculty is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding itself.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This fundamental principle of the necessary unity of apperception is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indeed an identical, and therefore analytical, proposition; but it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nevertheless explains the necessity for a synthesis of the manifold
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given in an intuition, without which the identity of self-consciousness
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: would be incogitable. For the ego, as a simple representation, presents
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: us with no manifold content; only in intuition, which is quite different
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the representation ego, can it be given us, and by means of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conjunction it is cogitated in one self-consciousness. An understanding,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself, would be intuitive; our understanding can only think and must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: look for its intuition to sense. I am, therefore, conscious of my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: identical self, in relation to all the variety of representations given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to me in an intuition, because I call all of them my representations. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other words, I am conscious myself of a necessary a priori synthesis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: my representations, which is called the original synthetical unity of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apperception, under which rank all the representations presented to me,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: think" and therefore could not be connected in one self-consciousness.

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: INTRODUCTION. Of the Transcendental Faculty of judgement in General.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If understanding in general be defined as the faculty of laws or rules,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these rules; that is, of distinguishing whether this or that does or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: does not stand under a given rule (casus datae legis). General logic
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contains no directions or precepts for the faculty of judgement, nor
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can it contain any such. For as it makes abstraction of all content of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition, no duty is left for it, except that of exposing analytically
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the mere form of cognition in conceptions, judgements, and conclusions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: understanding. Now if this logic wished to give some general direction
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: how we should subsume under these rules, that is, how we should
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the faculty of judgement. Thus, it is evident that the understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is capable of being instructed by rules, but that the judgement is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: peculiar talent, which does not, and cannot require tuition, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only exercise. This faculty is therefore the specific quality of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: In all subsumptions of an object under a conception, the representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the object must be homogeneous with the conception; in other words,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conception must contain that which is represented in the object to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be subsumed under it. For this is the meaning of the expression: "An
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object is contained under a conception." Thus the empirical conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of a plate is homogeneous with the pure geometrical conception of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: circle, inasmuch as the roundness which is cogitated in the former is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is the subsumption of the latter under the former, and consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other sensuous. Such a representation is the transcendental schema.

text: CHAPTER II. System of all Principles of the Pure Understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori. For this purpose, our table of the categories will certainly
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: afford us the natural and safe guidance. For it is precisely the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibility of the cognition of an object. Such a proof is necessary,

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle, that is, not merely to banish falsehood and error (in so far

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as it rests upon contradiction), but also for the cognition of truth.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: the object.

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: universal and fully sufficient Principle of all analytical cognition.

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conscious of the identity of the production of the one quantity with
