text: the production of the other; whereas axioms must be a priori synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: propositions. On the other hand, the self-evident propositions as to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation of numbers, are certainly synthetical but not universal, like
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: those of geometry, and for this reason cannot be called axioms, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: numerical formulae. That 7 + 5 = 12 is not an analytical proposition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For neither in the representation of seven, nor of five, nor of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition of the two numbers, do I cogitate the number twelve.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (Whether I cogitate the number in the addition of both, is not at
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: present the question; for in the case of an analytical proposition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the only point is whether I really cogitate the predicate in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of the subject.) But although the proposition is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthetical, it is nevertheless only a singular proposition. In so far
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as regard is here had merely to the synthesis of the homogeneous (the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: units), it cannot take place except in one manner, although our use
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of these numbers is afterwards general. If I say: "A triangle can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be constructed with three lines, any two of which taken together are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: greater than the third," I exercise merely the pure function of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: productive imagination, which may draw the lines longer or shorter and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: construct the angles at its pleasure. On the contrary, the number seven
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is possible only in one manner, and so is likewise the number twelve,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which results from the synthesis of seven and five. Such propositions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: then, cannot be termed axioms (for in that case we should have an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinity of these), but numerical formulae.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This transcendental principle of the mathematics of phenomena greatly
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: enlarges our a priori cognition. For it is by this principle alone that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure mathematics is rendered applicable in all its precision to objects
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of experience, and without it the validity of this application would not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be so self-evident; on the contrary, contradictions and confusions have
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: often arisen on this very point. Phenomena are not things in themselves.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Empirical intuition is possible only through pure intuition (of space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and time); consequently, what geometry affirms of the latter, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indisputably valid of the former. All evasions, such as the statement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that objects of sense do not conform to the rules of construction in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space (for example, to the rule of the infinite divisibility of lines or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: angles), must fall to the ground. For, if these objections hold good, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: deny to space, and with it to all mathematics, objective validity, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no longer know wherefore, and how far, mathematics can be applied to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena. The synthesis of spaces and times as the essential form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all intuition, is that which renders possible the apprehension of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon, and therefore every external experience, consequently all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition of the objects of experience; and whatever mathematics in its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure use proves of the former, must necessarily hold good of the latter.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: All objections are but the chicaneries of an ill-instructed reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which erroneously thinks to liberate the objects of sense from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: formal conditions of our sensibility, and represents these, although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mere phenomena, as things in themselves, presented as such to our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding. But in this case, no a priori synthetical cognition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them could be possible, consequently not through pure conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space and the science which determines these conceptions, that is to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: say, geometry, would itself be impossible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. ANTICIPATIONS OF PERCEPTION.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The principle of these is: In all phenomena the Real, that which is an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object of sensation, has Intensive Quantity, that is, has a Degree.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Perception is empirical consciousness, that is to say, a consciousness
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which contains an element of sensation. Phenomena as objects of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perception are not pure, that is, merely formal intuitions, like space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and time, for they cannot be perceived in themselves.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [Footnote: They can be perceived only as phenomena, and some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: part of them must always belong to the non-ego; whereas pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuitions are entirely the products of the mind itself, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as such are coguized IN THEMSELVES.--Tr]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: They contain, then, over and above the intuition, the materials for an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object (through which is represented something existing in space or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time), that is to say, they contain the real of sensation, as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation merely subjective, which gives us merely the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consciousness that the subject is affected, and which we refer to some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external object. Now, a gradual transition from empirical consciousness
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to pure consciousness is possible, inasmuch as the real in this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consciousness entirely vanishes, and there remains a merely formal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consciousness (a priori) of the manifold in time and space; consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there is possible a synthesis also of the production of the quantity of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a sensation from its commencement, that is, from the pure intuition = 0
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: onwards up to a certain quantity of the sensation. Now as sensation in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself is not an objective representation, and in it is to be found
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: neither the intuition of space nor of time, it cannot possess any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extensive quantity, and yet there does belong to it a quantity (and that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by means of its apprehension, in which empirical consciousness can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: within a certain time rise from nothing = 0 up to its given amount),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently an intensive quantity. And thus we must ascribe intensive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity, that is, a degree of influence on sense to all objects of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perception, in so far as this perception contains sensation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: All cognition, by means of which I am enabled to cognize and determine
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a priori what belongs to empirical cognition, may be called an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: anticipation; and without doubt this is the sense in which Epicurus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employed his expression prholepsis. But as there is in phenomena
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: something which is never cognized a priori, which on this account
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constitutes the proper difference between pure and empirical cognition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is to say, sensation (as the matter of perception), it follows,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that sensation is just that element in cognition which cannot be at
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all anticipated. On the other hand, we might very well term the pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determinations in space and time, as well in regard to figure as to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity, anticipations of phenomena, because they represent a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that which may always be given a posteriori in experience. But suppose
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that in every sensation, as sensation in general, without any particular
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensation being thought of, there existed something which could be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognized a priori, this would deserve to be called anticipation in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: special sense--special, because it may seem surprising to forestall
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, in that which concerns the matter of experience, and which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we can only derive from itself. Yet such really is the case here.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Apprehension*, by means of sensation alone, fills only one moment, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is, if I do not take into consideration a succession of many sensations.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: As that in the phenomenon, the apprehension of which is not a successive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis advancing from parts to an entire representation, sensation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: has therefore no extensive quantity; the want of sensation in a moment
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of time would represent it as empty, consequently = 0. That which in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the empirical intuition corresponds to sensation is reality (realitas
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phaenomenon); that which corresponds to the absence of it, negation = 0.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now every sensation is capable of a diminution, so that it can decrease,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and thus gradually disappear. Therefore, between reality in a phenomenon
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and negation, there exists a continuous concatenation of many possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intermediate sensations, the difference of which from each other is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always smaller than that between the given sensation and zero, or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complete negation. That is to say, the real in a phenomenon has always a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity, which however is not discoverable in apprehension, inasmuch as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apprehension take place by means of mere sensation in one instant, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not by the successive synthesis of many sensations, and therefore does
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not progress from parts to the whole. Consequently, it has a quantity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but not an extensive quantity.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: Apprehension is the Kantian word for preception, in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: largest sense in which we employ that term. It is the genus which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: includes under i, as species, perception proper and sensation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proper--Tr]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now that quantity which is apprehended only as unity, and in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: plurality can be represented only by approximation to negation = O,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I term intensive quantity. Consequently, reality in a phenomenon has
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intensive quantity, that is, a degree. If we consider this reality as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cause (be it of sensation or of another reality in the phenomenon, for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: example, a change), we call the degree of reality in its character of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cause a momentum, for example, the momentum of weight; and for this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, that the degree only indicates that quantity the apprehension of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is not successive, but instantaneous. This, however, I touch upon
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only in passing, for with causality I have at present nothing to do.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Accordingly, every sensation, consequently every reality in phenomena,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: however small it may be, has a degree, that is, an intensive quantity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which may always be lessened, and between reality and negation there
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exists a continuous connection of possible realities, and possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: smaller perceptions. Every colour--for example, red--has a degree,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which, be it ever so small, is never the smallest, and so is it always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with heat, the momentum of weight, etc.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This property of quantities, according to which no part of them is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: smallest possible (no part simple), is called their continuity. Space
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and time are quanta continua, because no part of them can be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given, without enclosing it within boundaries (points and moments),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently, this given part is itself a space or a time. Space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, consists only of spaces, and time of times. Points and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: moments are only boundaries, that is, the mere places or positions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: their limitation. But places always presuppose intuitions which are to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limit or determine them; and we cannot conceive either space or time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composed of constituent parts which are given before space or time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Such quantities may also be called flowing, because synthesis (of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: productive imagination) in the production of these quantities is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: progression in time, the continuity of which we are accustomed to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indicate by the expression flowing.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: All phenomena, then, are continuous quantities, in respect both to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition and mere perception (sensation, and with it reality). In the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: former case they are extensive quantities; in the latter, intensive.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: When the synthesis of the manifold of a phenomenon is interrupted, there
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: results merely an aggregate of several phenomena, and not properly a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon as a quantity, which is not produced by the mere continuation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the productive synthesis of a certain kind, but by the repetition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a synthesis always ceasing. For example, if I call thirteen dollars a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sum or quantity of money, I employ the term quite correctly, inasmuch as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I understand by thirteen dollars the value of a mark in standard silver,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is, to be sure, a continuous quantity, in which no part is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: smallest, but every part might constitute a piece of money, which would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contain material for still smaller pieces. If, however, by the words
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thirteen dollars I understand so many coins (be their value in silver
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: what it may), it would be quite erroneous to use the expression a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity of dollars; on the contrary, I must call them aggregate, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is, a number of coins. And as in every number we must have unity as the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: foundation, so a phenomenon taken as unity is a quantity, and as such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always a continuous quantity (quantum continuum).
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, seeing all phenomena, whether considered as extensive or intensive,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thing from one state into another) is continuous," might be proved here
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: easily, and with mathematical evidence, were it not that the causality
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: philosophy, and presupposes empirical principles. For of the possibility

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical can be admitted, we dare not, without injuring the unity of

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: which the principle above developed exercises in the anticipation of

text: 3. ANALOGIES OF EXPERIENCE.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The principle of these is: Experience is possible only through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of a necessary connection of Perceptions.

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Experience is an empirical cognition; that is to say, a cognition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely of intuition or sensation). Now in experience our perceptions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: come together contingently, so that no character of necessity in their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: A. FIRST ANALOGY.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Principle of the Permanence of Substance.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In all changes of phenomena, substance is permanent, and the quantum
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thereof in nature is neither increased nor diminished.

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: A philosopher was asked: "What is the weight of smoke?" He answered:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ashes, and you will have the weight of the smoke." Thus he presumed it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perish, but that only the form of it undergoes a change. In like manner
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: was the saying: "From nothing comes nothing," only another inference
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: The determinations of a substance, which are only particular modes of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its existence, are called accidents. They are always real, because they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which express the non-existence of something in the substance). Now,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: Now, upon this notion of permanence rests the proper notion of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception change. Origin and extinction are not changes of that which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: originates or becomes extinct. Change is but a mode of existence, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: follows on another mode of existence of the same object; hence all that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: changes is permanent, and only the condition thereof changes. Now since
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this mutation affects only determinations, which can have a beginning
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determinations cease, others begin."
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exists.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Substances (in the world of phenomena) are the substratum of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Our apprehension of the manifold of phenomena is always successive. The

text: Let us now proceed to our task. That something happens, that is to say,

text: C. THIRD ANALOGY.

text: Principle of Coexistence, According to the Law of Reciprocity or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Community.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: All substances, in so far as they can be perceived in space at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time, exist in a state of complete reciprocity of action.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Things are coexistent, when in empirical intuition the perception of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one can follow upon the perception of the other, and vice versa--which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: then the earth, or conversely, first the earth and then the moon; and

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: 4. THE POSTULATES OF EMPIRICAL THOUGHT.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 1. That which agrees with the formal conditions (intuition and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception) of experience, is possible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. That which coheres with the material conditions of experience
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (sensation), is real.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. That whose coherence with the real is determined according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: universal conditions of experience is (exists) necessary.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Explanation.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The categories of modality possess this peculiarity, that they do not in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the least determine the object, or enlarge the conception to which they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are annexed as predicates, but only express its relation to the faculty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of cognition. Though my conception of a thing is in itself complete, I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: am still entitled to ask whether the object of it is merely possible,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or whether it is also real, or, if the latter, whether it is also
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary. But hereby the object itself is not more definitely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determined in thought, but the question is only in what relation it,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: including all its determinations, stands to the understanding and its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employment in experience, to the empirical faculty of judgement, and to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the reason of its application to experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: more than explanations of the conceptions of possibility, reality, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all the categories to empirical use alone, not authorizing the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental employment of them. For if they are to have something
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: more than a merely logical significance, and to be something more than
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a mere analytical expression of the form of thought, and to have a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to things and their possibility, reality, or necessity, they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must concern possible experience and its synthetical unity, in which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: alone objects of cognition can be given.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The postulate of the possibility of things requires also, that the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the things agree with the formal conditions of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience in general. But this, that is to say, the objective form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, contains all the kinds of synthesis which are requisite for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I am conscious of my own existence as determined in time. All
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: me and not through the mere representation of a thing without me.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: The principles of modality are, however, not objectively synthetical,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: GENERAL REMARK ON THE SYSTEM OF PRINCIPLES.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: example, how a thing can be of the same sort with many others, that is,

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It is not at present our business to treat of empirical illusory
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: appearance (for example, optical illusion), which occurs in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical application of otherwise correct rules of the understanding,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and in which the judgement is misled by the influence of imagination.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Our purpose is to speak of transcendental illusory appearance, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: influences principles--that are not even applied to experience, for in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this case we should possess a sure test of their correctness--but which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: leads us, in disregard of all the warnings of criticism, completely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beyond the empirical employment of the categories and deludes us with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the chimera of an extension of the sphere of the pure understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We shall term those principles the application of which is confined
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: entirely within the limits of possible experience, immanent; those,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: on the other hand, which transgress these limits, we shall call
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendent principles. But by these latter I do not understand
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principles of the transcendental use or misuse of the categories, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is in reality a mere fault of the judgement when not under due restraint
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from criticism, and therefore not paying sufficient attention to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits of the sphere in which the pure understanding is allowed to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exercise its functions; but real principles which exhort us to break
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: down all those barriers, and to lay claim to a perfectly new field of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition, which recognizes no line of demarcation. Thus transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and transcendent are not identical terms. The principles of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure understanding, which we have already propounded, ought to be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of empirical and not of transcendental use, that is, they are not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: applicable to any object beyond the sphere of experience. A principle
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which removes these limits, nay, which authorizes us to overstep them,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is called transcendent. If our criticism can succeed in exposing the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: illusion in these pretended principles, those which are limited in their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employment to the sphere of experience may be called, in opposition to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the others, immanent principles of the pure understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Logical illusion, which consists merely in the imitation of the form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason (the illusion in sophistical syllogisms), arises entirely from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a want of due attention to logical rules. So soon as the attention
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is awakened to the case before us, this illusion totally disappears.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental illusion, on the contrary, does not cease to exist, even
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: after it has been exposed, and its nothingness clearly perceived by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: means of transcendental criticism. Take, for example, the illusion in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the proposition: "The world must have a beginning in time." The cause of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this is as follows. In our reason, subjectively considered as a faculty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of human cognition, there exist fundamental rules and maxims of its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exercise, which have completely the appearance of objective principles.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now from this cause it happens that the subjective necessity of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certain connection of our conceptions, is regarded as an objective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessity of the determination of things in themselves. This illusion it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is impossible to avoid, just as we cannot avoid perceiving that the sea
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: appears to be higher at a distance than it is near the shore, because we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: see the former by means of higher rays than the latter, or, which is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: still stronger case, as even the astronomer cannot prevent himself from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: seeing the moon larger at its rising than some time afterwards, although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: he is not deceived by this illusion.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental dialectic will therefore content itself with exposing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the illusory appearance in transcendental judgements, and guarding us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: against it; but to make it, as in the case of logical illusion, entirely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: disappear and cease to be illusion is utterly beyond its power. For we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: have here to do with a natural and unavoidable illusion, which rests
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon subjective principles and imposes these upon us as objective, while
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: logical dialectic, in the detection of sophisms, has to do merely with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an error in the logical consequence of the propositions, or with an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: artificially constructed illusion, in imitation of the natural error.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There is, therefore, a natural and unavoidable dialectic of pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason--not that in which the bungler, from want of the requisite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: knowledge, involves himself, nor that which the sophist devises for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: purpose of misleading, but that which is an inseparable adjunct of human
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, and which, even after its illusions have been exposed, does not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cease to deceive, and continually to lead reason into momentary errors,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which it becomes necessary continually to remove.

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which it makes abstraction of all content of cognition; but there is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions and principles, which it does not borrow either from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: senses or the understanding. The former faculty has been long defined by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: table of the functions of the former will present us with the clue to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conceptions of reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the former part of our transcendental logic, we defined the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from understanding as the faculty of principles.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The term principle is ambiguous, and commonly signifies merely a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself, and as regards its proper origin, entitled to the distinction.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: process of induction, may serve as the major in a syllogism; but it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can be only one straight line between two points) are general a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to the cases which can be subsumed under them. But I cannot for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the particular in the general by means of conceptions. Thus every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: syllogism is a form of the deduction of a cognition from a principle.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For the major always gives a conception, through which everything that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is subsumed under the condition thereof is cognized according to a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle. Now as every general cognition may serve as the major in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: syllogism, and the understanding presents us with such general a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori propositions, they may be termed principles, in respect of their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible use.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But if we consider these principles of the pure understanding in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to their origin, we shall find them to be anything rather
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: than cognitions from conceptions. For they would not even be possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a priori, if we could not rely on the assistance of pure intuition (in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematics), or on that of the conditions of a possible experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: That everything that happens has a cause, cannot be concluded from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happens a determinate empirical conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and they alone are entitled to be called principles. At the same time,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all general propositions may be termed comparative principles.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It has been a long-cherished wish--that (who knows how late), may one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: under which it subsists in perfect harmony with itself; they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: things is subordinated to principles and is to be determined, according
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The understanding may be a faculty for the production of unity of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, never applies directly to experience, or to any sensuous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: B. OF THE LOGICAL USE OF REASON.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: A distinction is commonly made between that which is immediately
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognized and that which is inferred or concluded. That in a figure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is bounded by three straight lines there are three angles, is an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immediate cognition; but that these angles are together equal to two
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: right angles, is an inference or conclusion. Now, as we are constantly
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employing this mode of thought and have thus become quite accustomed to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it, we no longer remark the above distinction, and, as in the case of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the so-called deceptions of sense, consider as immediately perceived,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: what has really been inferred. In every reasoning or syllogism, there
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is a fundamental proposition, afterwards a second drawn from it, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: finally the conclusion, which connects the truth in the first with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: truth in the second--and that infallibly. If the judgement concluded
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is so contained in the first proposition that it can be deduced from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it without the meditation of a third notion, the conclusion is called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immediate (consequentia immediata); I prefer the term conclusion of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding. But if, in addition to the fundamental cognition, a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: second judgement is necessary for the production of the conclusion, it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is called a conclusion of the reason. In the proposition: All men are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mortal, are contained the propositions: Some men are mortal, Nothing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is not mortal is a man, and these are therefore immediate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conclusions from the first. On the other hand, the proposition: all the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: learned are mortal, is not contained in the main proposition (for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of a learned man does not occur in it), and it can be deduced
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the main proposition only by means of a mediating judgement.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In every syllogism I first cogitate a rule (the major) by means of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding. In the next place I subsume a cognition under the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition of the rule (and this is the minor) by means of the judgement.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: And finally I determine my cognition by means of the predicate of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rule (this is the conclusio), consequently, I determine it a priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by means of the reason. The relations, therefore, which the major
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition, as the rule, represents between a cognition and its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition, constitute the different kinds of syllogisms. These are just
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: threefold--analogously with all judgements, in so far as they differ
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the mode of expressing the relation of a cognition in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding--namely, categorical, hypothetical, and disjunctive.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: When as often happens, the conclusion is a judgement which may follow
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from other given judgements, through which a perfectly different object
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is cogitated, I endeavour to discover in the understanding whether the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assertion in this conclusion does not stand under certain conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to a general rule. If I find such a condition, and if the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object mentioned in the conclusion can be subsumed under the given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: condition, then this conclusion follows from a rule which is also valid
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for other objects of cognition. From this we see that reason endeavours
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to subject the great variety of the cognitions of the understanding to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the smallest possible number of principles (general conditions), and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thus to produce in it the highest unity.

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There lurks in the procedure of rational Psychology a paralogism, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is represented in the following syllogism:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: That which cannot be cogitated otherwise than as subject, does not exist
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: otherwise than as subject, and is therefore substance.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: A thinking being, considered merely as such, cannot be cogitated
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: otherwise than as subject.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Therefore it exists also as such, that is, as substance.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the major we speak of a being that can be cogitated generally and in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every relation, consequently as it may be given in intuition. But in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: minor we speak of the same being only in so far as it regards itself as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject, relatively to thought and the unity of consciousness, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not in relation to intuition, by which it is presented as an object to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: dictionis.*

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: The proposition, "I think," or, "I exist thinking," is an empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition. But such a proposition must be based on empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition, and the object cogitated as a phenomenon; and thus our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: theory appears to maintain that the soul, even in thought, is merely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a phenomenon; and in this way our consciousness itself, in fact, abuts
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon nothing.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
