author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every respect) complete synthesis, whereby a phenomenon can be explained
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to the laws of the understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Secondly, it is properly the unconditioned alone that reason seeks in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this serially and regressively conducted synthesis of conditions. It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: wishes, to speak in another way, to attain to completeness in the series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of premisses, so as to render it unnecessary to presuppose others.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This unconditioned is always contained in the absolute totality of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series, when we endeavour to form a representation of it in thought.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But this absolutely complete synthesis is itself but an idea; for it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impossible, at least before hand, to know whether any such synthesis is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible in the case of phenomena. When we represent all existence in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thought by means of pure conceptions of the understanding, without any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions of sensuous intuition, we may say with justice that for a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given conditioned the whole series of conditions subordinated to each
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other is also given; for the former is only given through the latter.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But we find in the case of phenomena a particular limitation of the mode
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in which conditions are given, that is, through the successive synthesis
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the manifold of intuition, which must be complete in the regress. Now
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whether this completeness is sensuously possible, is a problem. But the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea of it lies in the reason--be it possible or impossible to connect
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with the idea adequate empirical conceptions. Therefore, as in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolute totality of the regressive synthesis of the manifold in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon (following the guidance of the categories, which represent it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as a series of conditions to a given conditioned) the unconditioned is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessarily contained--it being still left unascertained whether and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: how this totality exists; reason sets out from the idea of totality,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although its proper and final aim is the unconditioned--of the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series, or of a part thereof.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This unconditioned may be cogitated--either as existing only in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: entire series, all the members of which therefore would be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without exception conditioned and only the totality absolutely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconditioned--and in this case the regressus is called infinite; or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the absolutely unconditioned is only a part of the series, to which the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other members are subordinated, but which Is not itself submitted to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any other condition.* In the former case the series is a parte priori
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unlimited (without beginning), that is, infinite, and nevertheless
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completely given. But the regress in it is never completed, and can only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be called potentially infinite. In the second case there exists a first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the series. This first is called, in relation to past time, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beginning of the world; in relation to space, the limit of the world; in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to the parts of a given limited whole, the simple; in relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to causes, absolute spontaneity (liberty); and in relation to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence of changeable things, absolute physical necessity.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The absolute totality of the series of conditions to a given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned is always unconditioned; because beyond it there exist no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other conditions, on which it might depend. But the absolute totality of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: such a series is only an idea, or rather a problematical conception, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibility of which must be investigated--particularly in relation to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the mode in which the unconditioned, as the transcendental idea which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the real subject of inquiry, may be contained therein.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We possess two expressions, world and nature, which are generally
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: interchanged. The first denotes the mathematical total of all phenomena
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and the totality of their synthesis--in its progress by means of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition, as well as by division. And the world is termed nature,*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when it is regarded as a dynamical whole--when our attention is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: directed to the aggregation in space and time, for the purpose of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitating it as a quantity, but to the unity in the existence of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena. In this case the condition of that which happens is called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a cause; the unconditioned causality of the cause in a phenomenon is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: termed liberty; the conditioned cause is called in a more limited sense
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a natural cause. The conditioned in existence is termed contingent, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the unconditioned necessary. The unconditioned necessity of phenomena
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may be called natural necessity.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: Nature, understood adjective (formaliter), signifies the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complex of the determinations of a thing, connected according to an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: internal principle of causality. On the other hand, we understand by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nature, substantive (materialiter), the sum total of phenomena, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so far as they, by virtue of an internal principle of causality, are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connected with each other throughout. In the former sense we speak of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the nature of liquid matter, of fire, etc., and employ the word only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: adjective; while, if speaking of the objects of nature, we have in our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: minds the idea of a subsisting whole.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The ideas which we are at present engaged in discussing I have called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cosmological ideas; partly because by the term world is understood the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: entire content of all phenomena, and our ideas are directed solely to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the unconditioned among phenomena; partly also, because world, in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental sense, signifies the absolute totality of the content
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of existing things, and we are directing our attention only to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completeness of the synthesis--although, properly, only in regression.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In regard to the fact that these ideas are all transcendent, and,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although they do not transcend phenomena as regards their mode, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are concerned solely with the world of sense (and not with noumena),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nevertheless carry their synthesis to a degree far above all possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience--it still seems to me that we can, with perfect propriety,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: designate them cosmical conceptions. As regards the distinction between
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the mathematically and the dynamically unconditioned which is the aim of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the regression of the synthesis, I should call the two former, in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: more limited signification, cosmical conceptions, the remaining two
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendent physical conceptions. This distinction does not at present
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: seem to be of particular importance, but we shall afterwards find it to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be of some value.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION II. Antithetic of Pure Reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thetic is the term applied to every collection of dogmatical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: propositions. By antithetic I do not understand dogmatical assertions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the opposite, but the self-contradiction of seemingly dogmatical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognitions (thesis cum antithesis), in none of which we can discover
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any decided superiority. Antithetic is not, therefore, occupied with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one-sided statements, but is engaged in considering the contradictory
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nature of the general cognitions of reason and its causes.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental antithetic is an investigation into the antinomy of pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, its causes and result. If we employ our reason not merely in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the application of the principles of the understanding to objects of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, but venture with it beyond these boundaries, there arise
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certain sophistical propositions or theorems. These assertions have
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the following peculiarities: They can find neither confirmation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nor confutation in experience; and each is in itself not only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-consistent, but possesses conditions of its necessity in the very
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nature of reason--only that, unluckily, there exist just as valid and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary grounds for maintaining the contrary proposition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The questions which naturally arise in the consideration of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: dialectic of pure reason, are therefore: 1st. In what propositions is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure reason unavoidably subject to an antinomy? 2nd. What are the causes
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this antinomy? 3rd. Whether and in what way can reason free itself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from this self-contradiction?
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: A dialectical proposition or theorem of pure reason must, according
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to what has been said, be distinguishable from all sophistical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: propositions, by the fact that it is not an answer to an arbitrary
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: question, which may be raised at the mere pleasure of any person, but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to one which human reason must necessarily encounter in its progress. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the second place, a dialectical proposition, with its opposite, does not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: carry the appearance of a merely artificial illusion, which disappears
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as soon as it is investigated, but a natural and unavoidable illusion,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which, even when we are no longer deceived by it, continues to mock us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and, although rendered harmless, can never be completely removed.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This dialectical doctrine will not relate to the unity of understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in empirical conceptions, but to the unity of reason in pure ideas. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions of this doctrine are--inasmuch as it must, as a synthesis
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to rules, be conformable to the understanding, and at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time as the absolute unity of the synthesis, to the reason--that, if
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is adequate to the unity of reason, it is too great for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding, if according with the understanding, it is too small for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the reason. Hence arises a mutual opposition, which cannot be avoided,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: do what we will.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: These sophistical assertions of dialectic open, as it were, a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: battle-field, where that side obtains the victory which has been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: permitted to make the attack, and he is compelled to yield who has been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unfortunately obliged to stand on the defensive. And hence, champions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ability, whether on the right or on the wrong side, are certain to carry
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: away the crown of victory, if they only take care to have the right to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: make the last attack, and are not obliged to sustain another onset from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: their opponent. We can easily believe that this arena has been often
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: trampled by the feet of combatants, that many victories have been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: obtained on both sides, but that the last victory, decisive of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: affair between the contending parties, was won by him who fought for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: right, only if his adversary was forbidden to continue the tourney. As
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impartial umpires, we must lay aside entirely the consideration whether
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the combatants are fighting for the right or for the wrong side, for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the true or for the false, and allow the combat to be first decided.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Perhaps, after they have wearied more than injured each other, they
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: will discover the nothingness of their cause of quarrel and part good
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: friends.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This method of watching, or rather of originating, a conflict of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assertions, not for the purpose of finally deciding in favour of either
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: side, but to discover whether the object of the struggle is not a mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: illusion, which each strives in vain to reach, but which would be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no gain even when reached--this procedure, I say, may be termed the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sceptical method. It is thoroughly distinct from scepticism--the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle of a technical and scientific ignorance, which undermines
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the foundations of all knowledge, in order, if possible, to destroy
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our belief and confidence therein. For the sceptical method aims at
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certainty, by endeavouring to discover in a conflict of this kind,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conducted honestly and intelligently on both sides, the point
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of misunderstanding; just as wise legislators derive, from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: embarrassment of judges in lawsuits, information in regard to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: defective and ill-defined parts of their statutes. The antinomy which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reveals itself in the application of laws, is for our limited wisdom
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the best criterion of legislation. For the attention of reason, which in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstract speculation does not easily become conscious of its errors, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thus roused to the momenta in the determination of its principles.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But this sceptical method is essentially peculiar to transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophy, and can perhaps be dispensed with in every other field of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: investigation. In mathematics its use would be absurd; because in it no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: false assertions can long remain hidden, inasmuch as its demonstrations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must always proceed under the guidance of pure intuition, and by means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of an always evident synthesis. In experimental philosophy, doubt and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: delay may be very useful; but no misunderstanding is possible, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be easily removed; and in experience means of solving the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: difficulty and putting an end to the dissension must at last be found,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whether sooner or later. Moral philosophy can always exhibit its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principles, with their practical consequences, in concreto--at least in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible experiences, and thus escape the mistakes and ambiguities of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstraction. But transcendental propositions, which lay claim to insight
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beyond the region of possible experience, cannot, on the one hand,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exhibit their abstract synthesis in any a priori intuition, nor, on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other, expose a lurking error by the help of experience. Transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, therefore, presents us with no other criterion than that of an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: attempt to reconcile such assertions, and for this purpose to permit a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: free and unrestrained conflict between them. And this we now proceed to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: arrange.*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The antinomies stand in the order of the four transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ideas above detailed.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: FIRST CONFLICT OF THE TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The world has a beginning in time, and is also limited in regard to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Granted that the world has no beginning in time; up to every given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: moment of time, an eternity must have elapsed, and therewith passed away
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an infinite series of successive conditions or states of things in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world. Now the infinity of a series consists in the fact that it never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can be completed by means of a successive synthesis. It follows that an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite series already elapsed is impossible and that, consequently,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a beginning of the world is a necessary condition of its existence. And
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this was the first thing to be proved.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: As regards the second, let us take the opposite for granted. In this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: case, the world must be an infinite given total of coexistent things.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now we cannot cogitate the dimensions of a quantity, which is not given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: within certain limits of an intuition,* in any other way than by means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the synthesis of its parts, and the total of such a quantity only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by means of a completed synthesis, or the repeated addition of unity to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself. Accordingly, to cogitate the world, which fills all spaces, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a whole, the successive synthesis of the parts of an infinite world must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be looked upon as completed, that is to say, an infinite time must be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regarded as having elapsed in the enumeration of all co-existing things;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is impossible. For this reason an infinite aggregate of actual
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: things cannot be considered as a given whole, consequently, not as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contemporaneously given whole. The world is consequently, as regards
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extension in space, not infinite, but enclosed in limits. And this was
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the second thing to be proved.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: We may consider an undetermined quantity as a whole, when it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is enclosed within limits, although we cannot construct or ascertain
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its totality by measurement, that is, by the successive synthesis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its parts. For its limits of themselves determine its completeness as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whole.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ANTITHESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The world has no beginning, and no limits in space, but is, in relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: both to time and space, infinite.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For let it be granted that it has a beginning. A beginning is an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence which is preceded by a time in which the thing does not exist.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: On the above supposition, it follows that there must have been a time in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which the world did not exist, that is, a void time. But in a void time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the origination of a thing is impossible; because no part of any such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time contains a distinctive condition of being, in preference to that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: non-being (whether the supposed thing originate of itself, or by means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of some other cause). Consequently, many series of things may have a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beginning in the world, but the world itself cannot have a beginning,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and is, therefore, in relation to past time, infinite.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: As regards the second statement, let us first take the opposite for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: granted--that the world is finite and limited in space; it follows that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it must exist in a void space, which is not limited. We should therefore
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: meet not only with a relation of things in space, but also a relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of things to space. Now, as the world is an absolute whole, out of and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beyond which no object of intuition, and consequently no correlate to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which can be discovered, this relation of the world to a void space is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely a relation to no object. But such a relation, and consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the limitation of the world by void space, is nothing. Consequently,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world, as regards space, is not limited, that is, it is infinite in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regard to extension.*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: Space is merely the form of external intuition (formal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition), and not a real object which can be externally perceived.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Space, prior to all things which determine it (fill or limit it), or,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rather, which present an empirical intuition conformable to it, is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: under the title of absolute space, nothing but the mere possibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external phenomena, in so far as they either exist in themselves, or can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: annex themselves to given intuitions. Empirical intuition is therefore
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not a composition of phenomena and space (of perception and empty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition). The one is not the correlate of the other in a synthesis,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but they are vitally connected in the same empirical intuition, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: matter and form. If we wish to set one of these two apart from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the other--space from phenomena--there arise all sorts of empty

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: OBSERVATIONS ON THE FIRST ANTINOMY.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ON THE THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In bringing forward these conflicting arguments, I have not been on
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the search for sophisms, for the purpose of availing myself of special
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pleading, which takes advantage of the carelessness of the opposite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: party, appeals to a misunderstood statute, and erects its unrighteous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: claims upon an unfair interpretation. Both proofs originate fairly from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the nature of the case, and the advantage presented by the mistakes of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the dogmatists of both parties has been completely set aside.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The thesis might also have been unfairly demonstrated, by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: introduction of an erroneous conception of the infinity of a given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity. A quantity is infinite, if a greater than itself cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibly exist. The quantity is measured by the number of given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: units--which are taken as a standard--contained in it. Now no number can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be the greatest, because one or more units can always be added. It follows
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that an infinite given quantity, consequently an infinite world (both as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regards time and extension) is impossible. It is, therefore, limited in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: both respects. In this manner I might have conducted my proof; but the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception given in it does not agree with the true conception of an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite whole. In this there is no representation of its quantity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is not said how large it is; consequently its conception is not the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of a maximum. We cogitate in it merely its relation to an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: arbitrarily assumed unit, in relation to which it is greater than any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: number. Now, just as the unit which is taken is greater or smaller, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite will be greater or smaller; but the infinity, which consists
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely in the relation to this given unit, must remain always the same,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although the absolute quantity of the whole is not thereby cognized.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The true (transcendental) conception of infinity is: that the successive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis of unity in the measurement of a given quantum can never be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completed.* Hence it follows, without possibility of mistake, that an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: eternity of actual successive states up to a given (the present) moment
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot have elapsed, and that the world must therefore have a beginning.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The quantum in this sense contains a congeries of given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: units, which is greater than any number--and this is the mathematical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the infinite.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In regard to the second part of the thesis, the difficulty as to an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite and yet elapsed series disappears; for the manifold of a world
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite in extension is contemporaneously given. But, in order to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitate the total of this manifold, as we cannot have the aid of limits
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constituting by themselves this total in intuition, we are obliged to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: give some account of our conception, which in this case cannot proceed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the whole to the determined quantity of the parts, but must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: demonstrate the possibility of a whole by means of a successive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis of the parts. But as this synthesis must constitute a series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that cannot be completed, it is impossible for us to cogitate prior to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it, and consequently not by means of it, a totality. For the conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of totality itself is in the present case the representation of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: completed synthesis of the parts; and this completion, and consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its conception, is impossible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ON THE ANTITHESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The proof in favour of the infinity of the cosmical succession and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cosmical content is based upon the consideration that, in the opposite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: case, a void time and a void space must constitute the limits of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world. Now I am not unaware, that there are some ways of escaping this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conclusion. It may, for example, be alleged, that a limit to the world,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as regards both space and time, is quite possible, without at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time holding the existence of an absolute time before the beginning of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world, or an absolute space extending beyond the actual world--which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is impossible. I am quite well satisfied with the latter part of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: opinion of the philosophers of the Leibnitzian school. Space is merely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the form of external intuition, but not a real object which can itself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be externally intuited; it is not a correlate of phenomena, it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the form of phenomena itself. Space, therefore, cannot be regarded as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolutely and in itself something determinative of the existence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of things, because it is not itself an object, but only the form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible objects. Consequently, things, as phenomena, determine space;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is to say, they render it possible that, of all the possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: predicates of space (size and relation), certain may belong to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reality. But we cannot affirm the converse, that space, as something
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-subsistent, can determine real things in regard to size or shape,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for it is in itself not a real thing. Space (filled or void)* may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore be limited by phenomena, but phenomena cannot be limited by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an empty space without them. This is true of time also. All this being
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: granted, it is nevertheless indisputable, that we must assume these two
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nonentities, void space without and void time before the world, if we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: assume the existence of cosmical limits, relatively to space or time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: It is evident that what is meant here is, that empty space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in so far as it is limited by phenomena--space, that is, within the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world--does not at least contradict transcendental principles, and may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, as regards them, be admitted, although its possibility cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: on that account be affirmed.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, as regards the subterfuge adopted by those who endeavour to evade
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the consequence--that, if the world is limited as to space and time, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite void must determine the existence of actual things in regard
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to their dimensions--it arises solely from the fact that instead of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensuous world, an intelligible world--of which nothing is known--is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitated; instead of a real beginning (an existence, which is preceded
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by a period in which nothing exists), an existence which presupposes no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other condition than that of time; and, instead of limits of extension,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: boundaries of the universe. But the question relates to the mundus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phaenomenon, and its quantity; and in this case we cannot make
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstraction of the conditions of sensibility, without doing away with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the essential reality of this world itself. The world of sense, if it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limited, must necessarily lie in the infinite void. If this, and with it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space as the a priori condition of the possibility of phenomena, is left
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: out of view, the whole world of sense disappears. In our problem is this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: alone considered as given. The mundus intelligibilis is nothing but the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: general conception of a world, in which abstraction has been made of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all conditions of intuition, and in relation to which no synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition--either affirmative or negative--is possible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECOND CONFLICT OF TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Every composite substance in the world consists of simple parts; and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there exists nothing that is not either itself simple, or composed of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simple parts.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, grant that composite substances do not consist of simple parts;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in this case, if all combination or composition were annihilated in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thought, no composite part, and (as, by the supposition, there do
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not exist simple parts) no simple part would exist. Consequently,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no substance; consequently, nothing would exist. Either, then, it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is impossible to annihilate composition in thought; or, after such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: annihilation, there must remain something that subsists without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition, that is, something that is simple. But in the former case
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the composite could not itself consist of substances, because with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substances composition is merely a contingent relation, apart from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which they must still exist as self-subsistent beings. Now, as this case
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradicts the supposition, the second must contain the truth--that the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substantial composite in the world consists of simple parts.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows, as an immediate inference, that the things in the world are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all, without exception, simple beings--that composition is merely an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: external condition pertaining to them--and that, although we never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can separate and isolate the elementary substances from the state of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition, reason must cogitate these as the primary subjects of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all composition, and consequently, as prior thereto--and as simple
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substances.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ANTITHESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: No composite thing in the world consists of simple parts; and there does
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not exist in the world any simple substance.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Let it be supposed that a composite thing (as substance) consists
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of simple parts. Inasmuch as all external relation, consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all composition of substances, is possible only in space; the space,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: occupied by that which is composite, must consist of the same number of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts as is contained in the composite. But space does not consist of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simple parts, but of spaces. Therefore, every part of the composite must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: occupy a space. But the absolutely primary parts of what is composite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are simple. It follows that what is simple occupies a space. Now, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: everything real that occupies a space, contains a manifold the parts of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which are external to each other, and is consequently composite--and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a real composite, not of accidents (for these cannot exist external to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other apart from substance), but of substances--it follows that the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simple must be a substantial composite, which is self-contradictory.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The second proposition of the antithesis--that there exists in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world nothing that is simple--is here equivalent to the following:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The existence of the absolutely simple cannot be demonstrated from any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience or perception either external or internal; and the absolutely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simple is a mere idea, the objective reality of which cannot be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: demonstrated in any possible experience; it is consequently, in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exposition of phenomena, without application and object. For, let us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: take for granted that an object may be found in experience for this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental idea; the empirical intuition of such an object must then
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be recognized to contain absolutely no manifold with its parts external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to each other, and connected into unity. Now, as we cannot reason from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the non-consciousness of such a manifold to the impossibility of its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence in the intuition of an object, and as the proof of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impossibility is necessary for the establishment and proof of absolute
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simplicity; it follows that this simplicity cannot be inferred from any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perception whatever. As, therefore, an absolutely simple object cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be given in any experience, and the world of sense must be considered as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the sum total of all possible experiences: nothing simple exists in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This second proposition in the antithesis has a more extended aim than
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the first. The first merely banishes the simple from the intuition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the composite; while the second drives it entirely out of nature. Hence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we were unable to demonstrate it from the conception of a given object
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of external intuition (of the composite), but we were obliged to prove
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it from the relation of a given object to a possible experience in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: general.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: OBSERVATIONS ON THE SECOND ANTINOMY.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: When I speak of a whole, which necessarily consists of simple parts, I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understand thereby only a substantial whole, as the true composite; that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is to say, I understand that contingent unity of the manifold which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given as perfectly isolated (at least in thought), placed in reciprocal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connection, and thus constituted a unity. Space ought not to be called a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: compositum but a totum, for its parts are possible in the whole, and not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the whole by means of the parts. It might perhaps be called a compositum
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ideale, but not a compositum reale. But this is of no importance. As
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space is not a composite of substances (and not even of real accidents),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: if I abstract all composition therein--nothing, not even a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: point, remains; for a point is possible only as the limit of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space--consequently of a composite. Space and time, therefore, do not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consist of simple parts. That which belongs only to the condition or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: state of a substance, even although it possesses a quantity (motion or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: change, for example), likewise does not consist of simple parts. That is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to say, a certain degree of change does not originate from the addition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of many simple changes. Our inference of the simple from the composite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is valid only of self-subsisting things. But the accidents of a state
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are not self-subsistent. The proof, then, for the necessity of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: simple, as the component part of all that is substantial and composite,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may prove a failure, and the whole case of this thesis be lost, if we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: carry the proposition too far, and wish to make it valid of everything
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is composite without distinction--as indeed has really now and then
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happened. Besides, I am here speaking only of the simple, in so far as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is necessarily given in the composite--the latter being capable
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of solution into the former as its component parts. The proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Causality according to the laws of nature, is not the only causality

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Let it be supposed, that there is no other kind of causality than that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: FOURTH CONFLICT OF THE TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: THESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There exists either in, or in connection with the world--either as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: part of it, or as the cause of it--an absolutely necessary being.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The world of sense, as the sum total of all phenomena, contains a series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of changes. For, without such a series, the mental representation of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the series of time itself, as the condition of the possibility of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sensuous world, could not be presented to us.* But every change stands
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: under its condition, which precedes it in time and renders it necessary.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now the existence of a given condition presupposes a complete series of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions up to the absolutely unconditioned, which alone is absolutely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary. It follows that something that is absolutely necessary must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exist, if change exists as its consequence. But this necessary thing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself belongs to the sensuous world. For suppose it to exist out of and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apart from it, the series of cosmical changes would receive from it a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beginning, and yet this necessary cause would not itself belong to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world of sense. But this is impossible. For, as the beginning of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series in time is determined only by that which precedes it in time, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supreme condition of the beginning of a series of changes must exist
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the time in which this series itself did not exist; for a beginning
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supposes a time preceding, in which the thing that begins to be was
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not in existence. The causality of the necessary cause of changes,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and consequently the cause itself, must for these reasons belong
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to time--and to phenomena, time being possible only as the form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena. Consequently, it cannot be cogitated as separated from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world of sense--the sum total of all phenomena. There is, therefore,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contained in the world, something that is absolutely necessary--whether
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: ANTITHESIS.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: An absolutely necessary being does not exist, either in the world, or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: out of it--as its cause.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: PROOF.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Grant that either the world itself is necessary, or that there is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contained in it a necessary existence. Two cases are possible. First,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: there must either be in the series of cosmical changes a beginning,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is unconditionally necessary, and therefore uncaused--which is at
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: variance with the dynamical law of the determination of all phenomena
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in time; or, secondly, the series itself is without beginning, and,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: although contingent and conditioned in all its parts, is nevertheless
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolutely necessary and unconditioned as a whole--which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-contradictory. For the existence of an aggregate cannot be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary, if no single part of it possesses necessary existence.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Grant, on the other band, that an absolutely necessary cause exists out
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of and apart from the world. This cause, as the highest member in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series of the causes of cosmical changes, must originate or begin* the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence of the latter and their series. In this case it must also
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: begin to act, and its causality would therefore belong to time, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently to the sum total of phenomena, that is, to the world.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows that the cause cannot be out of the world; which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contradictory to the hypothesis. Therefore, neither in the world, nor
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: out of it (but in causal connection with it), does there exist any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: it as we may. And this is actually the case with all cosmological

text: conceptions, which, for the reason above mentioned, involve reason, so
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: long as it remains attached to them, in an unavoidable antinomy. For
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: suppose:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: First, that the world has no beginning--in this case it is too large
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for our conception; for this conception, which consists in a successive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress, cannot overtake the whole eternity that has elapsed. Grant
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that it has a beginning, it is then too small for the conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding. For, as a beginning presupposes a time preceding, it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be unconditioned; and the law of the empirical employment of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding imposes the necessity of looking for a higher condition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time; and the world is, therefore, evidently too small for this law.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The same is the case with the double answer to the question regarding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the extent, in space, of the world. For, if it is infinite and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unlimited, it must be too large for every possible empirical conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If it is finite and limited, we have a right to ask: "What determines
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these limits?" Void space is not a self-subsistent correlate of things,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and cannot be a final condition--and still less an empirical condition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: forming a part of a possible experience. For how can we have any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience or perception of an absolute void? But the absolute totality
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the empirical synthesis requires that the unconditioned be an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical conception. Consequently, a finite world is too small for our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Secondly, if every phenomenon (matter) in space consists of an infinite
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: number of parts, the regress of the division is always too great for our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception; and if the division of space must cease with some member
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the division (the simple), it is too small for the idea of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconditioned. For the member at which we have discontinued our division
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: still admits a regress to many more parts contained in the object.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thirdly, suppose that every event in the world happens in accordance
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with the laws of nature; the causality of a cause must itself be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an event and necessitates a regress to a still higher cause, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently the unceasing prolongation of the series of conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a parte priori. Operative nature is therefore too large for every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception we can form in the synthesis of cosmical events.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If we admit the existence of spontaneously produced events, that is, of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: free agency, we are driven, in our search for sufficient reasons, on an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unavoidable law of nature and are compelled to appeal to the empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: law of causality, and we find that any such totality of connection in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our synthesis is too small for our necessary empirical conception.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Fourthly, if we assume the existence of an absolutely necessary
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: being--whether it be the world or something in the world, or the cause
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the world--we must place it in a time at an infinite distance from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any given moment; for, otherwise, it must be dependent on some other and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: higher existence. Such an existence is, in this case, too large for our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical conception, and unattainable by the continued regress of any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But if we believe that everything in the world--be it condition or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned--is contingent; every given existence is too small for our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception. For in this case we are compelled to seek for some other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence upon which the former depends.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We have said that in all these cases the cosmological idea is either
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: too great or too small for the empirical regress in a synthesis, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently for every possible conception of the understanding. Why did
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we not express ourselves in a manner exactly the reverse of this and,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: instead of accusing the cosmological idea of over stepping or of falling
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: short of its true aim, possible experience, say that, in the first case,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the empirical conception is always too small for the idea, and in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: second too great, and thus attach the blame of these contradictions to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the empirical regress? The reason is this. Possible experience can alone
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: give reality to our conceptions; without it a conception is merely an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea, without truth or relation to an object. Hence a possible empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception must be the standard by which we are to judge whether an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea is anything more than an idea and fiction of thought, or whether it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relates to an object in the world. If we say of a thing that in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to some other thing it is too large or too small, the former is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: considered as existing for the sake of the latter, and requiring to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be adapted to it. Among the trivial subjects of discussion in the old
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: schools of dialectics was this question: "If a ball cannot pass through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a hole, shall we say that the ball is too large or the hole too small?"
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In this case it is indifferent what expression we employ; for we do
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not know which exists for the sake of the other. On the other hand, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot say: "The man is too long for his coat"; but: "The coat is too
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: short for the man."
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We are thus led to the well-founded suspicion that the cosmological
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ideas, and all the conflicting sophistical assertions connected with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them, are based upon a false and fictitious conception of the mode in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which the object of these ideas is presented to us; and this suspicion
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: will probably direct us how to expose the illusion that has so long led
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: us astray from the truth.
