text: SECTION VI. Transcendental Idealism as the Key to theSolution
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of Pure Cosmological Dialectic.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the transcendental aesthetic we proved that everything intuited in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: space and time, all objects of a possible experience, are nothing but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena, that is, mere representations; and that these, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presented to us--as extended bodies, or as series of changes--have no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-subsistent existence apart from human thought. This doctrine I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: call Transcendental Idealism.* The realist in the transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sense regards these modifications of our sensibility, these mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representations, as things subsisting in themselves.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: I have elsewhere termed this theory formal idealism, to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguish it from material idealism, which doubts or denies the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence of external things. To avoid ambiguity, it seems advisable in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: many cases to employ this term instead of that mentioned in the text.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It would be unjust to accuse us of holding the long-decried theory of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical idealism, which, while admitting the reality of space, denies,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or at least doubts, the existence of bodies extended in it, and thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: leaves us without a sufficient criterion of reality and illusion. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supporters of this theory find no difficulty in admitting the reality of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the phenomena of the internal sense in time; nay, they go the length
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of maintaining that this internal experience is of itself a sufficient
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proof of the real existence of its object as a thing in itself.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental idealism allows that the objects of external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition--as intuited in space, and all changes in time--as represented
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by the internal sense, are real. For, as space is the form of that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition which we call external, and, without objects in space, no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical representation could be given us, we can and ought to regard
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extended bodies in it as real. The case is the same with representations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in time. But time and space, with all phenomena therein, are not in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves things. They are nothing but representations and cannot exist
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: out of and apart from the mind. Nay, the sensuous internal intuition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the mind (as the object of consciousness), the determination of which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is represented by the succession of different states in time, is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the real, proper self, as it exists in itself--not the transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject--but only a phenomenon, which is presented to the sensibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this, to us, unknown being. This internal phenomenon cannot be admitted
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to be a self-subsisting thing; for its condition is time, and time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be the condition of a thing in itself. But the empirical truth
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of phenomena in space and time is guaranteed beyond the possibility of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: doubt, and sufficiently distinguished from the illusion of dreams
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or fancy--although both have a proper and thorough connection in an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience according to empirical laws. The objects of experience then
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are not things in themselves, but are given only in experience, and have
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no existence apart from and independently of experience. That there may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be inhabitants in the moon, although no one has ever observed them, must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certainly be admitted; but this assertion means only, that we may in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible progress of experience discover them at some future time. For
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that which stands in connection with a perception according to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: laws of the progress of experience is real. They are therefore really
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existent, if they stand in empirical connection with my actual or real
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consciousness, although they are not in themselves real, that is, apart
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the progress of experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There is nothing actually given--we can be conscious of nothing as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: real, except a perception and the empirical progression from it to other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible perceptions. For phenomena, as mere representations, are real
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only in perception; and perception is, in fact, nothing but the reality
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of an empirical representation, that is, a phenomenon. To call a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon a real thing prior to perception means either that we must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: meet with this phenomenon in the progress of experience, or it means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nothing at all. For I can say only of a thing in itself that it exists
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: without relation to the senses and experience. But we are speaking here
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely of phenomena in space and time, both of which are determinations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of sensibility, and not of things in themselves. It follows that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena are not things in themselves, but are mere representations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which if not given in us--in perception--are non-existent.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The faculty of sensuous intuition is properly a receptivity--a capacity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of being affected in a certain manner by representations, the relation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of which to each other is a pure intuition of space and time--the pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: forms of sensibility. These representations, in so far as they are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connected and determinable in this relation (in space and time)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: according to laws of the unity of experience, are called objects. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: non-sensuous cause of these representations is completely unknown to us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and hence cannot be intuited as an object. For such an object could not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be represented either in space or in time; and without these conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition or representation is impossible. We may, at the same time,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: term the non-sensuous cause of phenomena the transcendental object--but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: merely as a mental correlate to sensibility, considered as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: receptivity. To this transcendental object we may attribute the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connection and extent of our possible perceptions, and say that it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given and exists in itself prior to all experience. But the phenomena,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: corresponding to it, are not given as things in themselves, but in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience alone. For they are mere representations, receiving from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perceptions alone significance and relation to a real object, under
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the condition that this or that perception--indicating an object--is in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complete connection with all others in accordance with the rules of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity of experience. Thus we can say: "The things that really existed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in past time are given in the transcendental object of experience." But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these are to me real objects, only in so far as I can represent to my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: own mind, that a regressive series of possible perceptions--following
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the indications of history, or the footsteps of cause and effect--in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: accordance with empirical laws--that, in one word, the course of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world conducts us to an elapsed series of time as the condition of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: present time. This series in past time is represented as real, not in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself, but only in connection with a possible experience. Thus, when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I say that certain events occurred in past time, I merely assert the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibility of prolonging the chain of experience, from the present
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perception, upwards to the conditions that determine it according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If I represent to myself all objects existing in all space and time, I
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: do not thereby place these in space and time prior to all experience; on
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the contrary, such a representation is nothing more than the notion of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a possible experience, in its absolute completeness. In experience alone
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are those objects, which are nothing but representations, given. But,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when I say they existed prior to my experience, this means only that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I must begin with the perception present to me and follow the track
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indicated until I discover them in some part or region of experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The cause of the empirical condition of this progression--and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently at what member therein I must stop, and at what point

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the regress I am to find this member--is transcendental, and hence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessarily incognizable. But with this we have not to do; our concern
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is only with the law of progression in experience, in which objects,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, phenomena, are given. It is a matter of indifference, whether
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I say, "I may in the progress of experience discover stars, at a hundred
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: times greater distance than the most distant of those now visible," or,

text: or ever will discover them." For, if they are given as things in

text: SECTION VII. Critical Solution of the Cosmological Problem.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The antinomy of pure reason is based upon the following dialectical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: argument: "If that which is conditioned is given, the whole series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of its conditions is also given; but sensuous objects are given as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned; consequently..." This syllogism, the major of which seems
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so natural and evident, introduces as many cosmological ideas as there
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are different kinds of conditions in the synthesis of phenomena, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so far as these conditions constitute a series. These ideas require
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolute totality in the series, and thus place reason in inextricable
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: embarrassment. Before proceeding to expose the fallacy in this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: dialectical argument, it will be necessary to have a correct
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding of certain conceptions that appear in it.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In the first place, the following proposition is evident, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indubitably certain: "If the conditioned is given, a regress in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series of all its conditions is thereby imperatively required." For the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: very conception of a conditioned is a conception of something related
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to a condition, and, if this condition is itself conditioned, to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: another condition--and so on through all the members of the series.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This proposition is, therefore, analytical and has nothing to fear
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from transcendental criticism. It is a logical postulate of reason:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to pursue, as far as possible, the connection of a conception with its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions.

text: falsehood of the constitutive principle, and prevent us from attributing

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (by a transcendental subreptio) objective reality to an idea, which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: valid only as a rule.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In order to understand the proper meaning of this rule of pure reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we must notice first that it cannot tell us what the object is, but only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: how the empirical regress is to be proceeded with in order to attain to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the complete conception of the object. If it gave us any information in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: respect to the former statement, it would be a constitutive principle--a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle impossible from the nature of pure reason. It will not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore enable us to establish any such conclusions as: "The series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of conditions for a given conditioned is in itself finite," or, "It is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite." For, in this case, we should be cogitating in the mere idea
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of absolute totality, an object which is not and cannot be given in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience; inasmuch as we should be attributing a reality objective and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: independent of the empirical synthesis, to a series of phenomena. This
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea of reason cannot then be regarded as valid--except as a rule for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the regressive synthesis in the series of conditions, according to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which we must proceed from the conditioned, through all intermediate and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subordinate conditions, up to the unconditioned; although this goal is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unattained and unattainable. For the absolutely unconditioned cannot be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: discovered in the sphere of experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We now proceed to determine clearly our notion of a synthesis which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can never be complete. There are two terms commonly employed for this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: purpose. These terms are regarded as expressions of different and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distinguishable notions, although the ground of the distinction has
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: never been clearly exposed. The term employed by the mathematicians
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is progressus in infinitum. The philosophers prefer the expression
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: progressus in indefinitum. Without detaining the reader with an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: examination of the reasons for such a distinction, or with remarks
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: on the right or wrong use of the terms, I shall endeavour clearly to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determine these conceptions, so far as is necessary for the purpose in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this Critique.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We may, with propriety, say of a straight line, that it may be produced
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to infinity. In this case the distinction between a progressus in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinitum and a progressus in indefinitum is a mere piece of subtlety.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, although when we say, "Produce a straight line," it is more correct
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to say in indefinitum than in infinitum; because the former means,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: "Produce it as far as you please," the second, "You must not cease to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: produce it"; the expression in infinitum is, when we are speaking of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: power to do it, perfectly correct, for we can always make it longer if
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we please--on to infinity. And this remark holds good in all cases, when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we speak of a progressus, that is, an advancement from the condition to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the conditioned; this possible advancement always proceeds to infinity.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We may proceed from a given pair in the descending line of generation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from father to son, and cogitate a never-ending line of descendants from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it. For in such a case reason does not demand absolute totality in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series, because it does not presuppose it as a condition and as given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (datum), but merely as conditioned, and as capable of being given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (dabile).
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Very different is the case with the problem: "How far the regress, which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ascends from the given conditioned to the conditions, must extend";
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whether I can say: "It is a regress in infinitum," or only "in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indefinitum"; and whether, for example, setting out from the human
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: beings at present alive in the world, I may ascend in the series of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: their ancestors, in infinitum--mr whether all that can be said is, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so far as I have proceeded, I have discovered no empirical ground for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: considering the series limited, so that I am justified, and indeed,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: compelled to search for ancestors still further back, although I am not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: obliged by the idea of reason to presuppose them.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: My answer to this question is: "If the series is given in empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition as a whole, the regress in the series of its internal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions proceeds in infinitum; but, if only one member of the series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is given, from which the regress is to proceed to absolute totality, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress is possible only in indefinitum." For example, the division of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a portion of matter given within certain limits--of a body, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is--proceeds in infinitum. For, as the condition of this whole is its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: part, and the condition of the part a part of the part, and so on, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as in this regress of decomposition an unconditioned indivisible member
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the series of conditions is not to be found; there are no reasons
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or grounds in experience for stopping in the division, but, on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contrary, the more remote members of the division are actually and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirically given prior to this division. That is to say, the division
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proceeds to infinity. On the other hand, the series of ancestors of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any given human being is not given, in its absolute totality, in any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, and yet the regress proceeds from every genealogical member
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this series to one still higher, and does not meet with any empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limit presenting an absolutely unconditioned member of the series.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But as the members of such a series are not contained in the empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition of the whole, prior to the regress, this regress does not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proceed to infinity, but only in indefinitum, that is, we are called
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon to discover other and higher members, which are themselves always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In neither case--the regressus in infinitum, nor the regressus in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indefinitum, is the series of conditions to be considered as actually
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite in the object itself. This might be true of things in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves, but it cannot be asserted of phenomena, which, as conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of each other, are only given in the empirical regress itself. Hence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the question no longer is, "What is the quantity of this series of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions in itself--is it finite or infinite?" for it is nothing in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself; but, "How is the empirical regress to be commenced, and how
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: far ought we to proceed with it?" And here a signal distinction in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the application of this rule becomes apparent. If the whole is given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirically, it is possible to recede in the series of its internal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions to infinity. But if the whole is not given, and can only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be given by and through the empirical regress, I can only say: "It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is possible to infinity, to proceed to still higher conditions in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the series." In the first case, I am justified in asserting that more
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: members are empirically given in the object than I attain to in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress (of decomposition). In the second case, I am justified only in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: saying, that I can always proceed further in the regress, because no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: member of the series is given as absolutely conditioned, and thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a higher member is possible, and an inquiry with regard to it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary. In the one case it is necessary to find other members of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series, in the other it is necessary to inquire for others, inasmuch as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience presents no absolute limitation of the regress. For, either
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: you do not possess a perception which absolutely limits your empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress, and in this case the regress cannot be regarded as complete;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or, you do possess such a limitative perception, in which case it is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a part of your series (for that which limits must be distinct from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that which is limited by it), and it is incumbent you to continue your
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress up to this condition, and so on.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: These remarks will be placed in their proper light by their application
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the following section.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION IX. Of the Empirical Use of the Regulative Principle of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Reason with regard to the Cosmological Ideas.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We have shown that no transcendental use can be made either of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions of reason or of understanding. We have shown, likewise, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the demand of absolute totality in the series of conditions in the world
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of sense arises from a transcendental employment of reason, resting on
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the opinion that phenomena are to be regarded as things in themselves.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows that we are not required to answer the question respecting
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the absolute quantity of a series--whether it is in itself limited or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unlimited. We are only called upon to determine how far we must proceed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the empirical regress from condition to condition, in order to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: discover, in conformity with the rule of reason, a full and correct
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: answer to the questions proposed by reason itself.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This principle of reason is hence valid only as a rule for the extension
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of a possible experience--its invalidity as a principle constitutive of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena in themselves having been sufficiently demonstrated. And thus,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: too, the antinomial conflict of reason with itself is completely put an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: end to; inasmuch as we have not only presented a critical solution of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the fallacy lurking in the opposite statements of reason, but have shown
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the true meaning of the ideas which gave rise to these statements. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: dialectical principle of reason has, therefore, been changed into a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: doctrinal principle. But in fact, if this principle, in the subjective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: signification which we have shown to be its only true sense, may be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: guaranteed as a principle of the unceasing extension of the employment
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of our understanding, its influence and value are just as great as if
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it were an axiom for the a priori determination of objects. For such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an axiom could not exert a stronger influence on the extension and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rectification of our knowledge, otherwise than by procuring for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principles of the understanding the most widely expanded employment in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the field of experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Composition of Phenomena in the Universe.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Here, as well as in the case of the other cosmological problems, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ground of the regulative principle of reason is the proposition that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in our empirical regress no experience of an absolute limit, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently no experience of a condition, which is itself absolutely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconditioned, is discoverable. And the truth of this proposition itself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rests upon the consideration that such an experience must represent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to us phenomena as limited by nothing or the mere void, on which our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: continued regress by means of perception must abut--which is impossible.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now this proposition, which declares that every condition attained in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the empirical regress must itself be considered empirically conditioned,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contains the rule in terminis, which requires me, to whatever extent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I may have proceeded in the ascending series, always to look for some
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: higher member in the series--whether this member is to become known to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: me through experience, or not.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Nothing further is necessary, then, for the solution of the first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cosmological problem, than to decide, whether, in the regress to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconditioned quantity of the universe (as regards space and time),
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this never limited ascent ought to be called a regressus in infinitum or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indefinitum.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The general representation which we form in our minds of the series of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all past states or conditions of the world, or of all the things which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: at present exist in it, is itself nothing more than a possible empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress, which is cogitated--although in an undetermined manner--in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mind, and which gives rise to the conception of a series of conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for a given object.* Now I have a conception of the universe, but not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an intuition--that is, not an intuition of it as a whole. Thus I cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infer the magnitude of the regress from the quantity or magnitude of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world, and determine the former by means of the latter; on the contrary,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I must first of all form a conception of the quantity or magnitude
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the world from the magnitude of the empirical regress. But of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress I know nothing more than that I ought to proceed from every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given member of the series of conditions to one still higher. But the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity of the universe is not thereby determined, and we cannot affirm
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that this regress proceeds in infinitum. Such an affirmation would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: anticipate the members of the series which have not yet been reached,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and represent the number of them as beyond the grasp of any empirical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis; it would consequently determine the cosmical quantity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: prior to the regress (although only in a negative manner)--which is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impossible. For the world is not given in its totality in any intuition:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently, its quantity cannot be given prior to the regress. It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: follows that we are unable to make any declaration respecting the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cosmical quantity in itself--not even that the regress in it is a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress in infinitum; we must only endeavour to attain to a conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the quantity of the universe, in conformity with the rule which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determines the empirical regress in it. But this rule merely requires
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: us never to admit an absolute limit to our series--how far soever we may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: have proceeded in it, but always, on the contrary, to subordinate every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon to some other as its condition, and consequently to proceed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to this higher phenomenon. Such a regress is, therefore, the regressus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in indefinitum, which, as not determining a quantity in the object, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: clearly distinguishable from the regressus in infinitum.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The cosmical series can neither be greater nor smaller than
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the possible empirical regress, upon which its conception is based. And
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as this regress cannot be a determinate infinite regress, still less a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determinate finite (absolutely limited), it is evident that we cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regard the world as either finite or infinite, because the regress,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which gives us the representation of the world, is neither finite nor
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows from what we have said that we are not justified in declaring
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world to be infinite in space, or as regards past time. For this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of an infinite given quantity is empirical; but we cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: apply the conception of an infinite quantity to the world as an object
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the senses. I cannot say, "The regress from a given perception to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: everything limited either in space or time, proceeds in infinitum," for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: this presupposes an infinite cosmical quantity; neither can I say, "It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is finite," for an absolute limit is likewise impossible in experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows that I am not entitled to make any assertion at all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: respecting the whole object of experience--the world of sense; I must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limit my declarations to the rule according to which experience or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical knowledge is to be attained.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: To the question, therefore, respecting the cosmical quantity, the first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and negative answer is: "The world has no beginning in time, and no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolute limit in space."
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, in the contrary case, it would be limited by a void time on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: one hand, and by a void space on the other. Now, since the world, as a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenon, cannot be thus limited in itself for a phenomenon is not a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thing in itself; it must be possible for us to have a perception of this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limitation by a void time and a void space. But such a perception--such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an experience is impossible; because it has no content. Consequently,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an absolute cosmical limit is empirically, and therefore absolutely,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: impossible.*
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The reader will remark that the proof presented above is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: very different from the dogmatical demonstration given in the antithesis
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the first antinomy. In that demonstration, it was taken for granted
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that the world is a thing in itself--given in its totality prior to

text: all regress, and a determined position in space and time was denied to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it--if it was not considered as occupying all time and all space. Hence
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our conclusion differed from that given above; for we inferred in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: antithesis the actual infinity of the world.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: From this follows the affirmative answer: "The regress in the series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of phenomena--as a determination of the cosmical quantity, proceeds in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: indefinitum." This is equivalent to saying: "The world of sense has no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: absolute quantity, but the empirical regress (through which alone the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world of sense is presented to us on the side of its conditions) rests
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon a rule, which requires it to proceed from every member of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: series, as conditioned, to one still more remote (whether through
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: personal experience, or by means of history, or the chain of cause and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: effect), and not to cease at any point in this extension of the possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical employment of the understanding." And this is the proper and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only use which reason can make of its principles.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The above rule does not prescribe an unceasing regress in one kind of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena. It does not, for example, forbid us, in our ascent from an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: individual human being through the line of his ancestors, to expect that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we shall discover at some point of the regress a primeval pair, or to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: admit, in the series of heavenly bodies, a sun at the farthest possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: distance from some centre. All that it demands is a perpetual progress
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from phenomena to phenomena, even although an actual perception is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presented by them (as in the case of our perceptions being so weak
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as that we are unable to become conscious of them), since they,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nevertheless, belong to possible experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Every beginning is in time, and all limits to extension are in space.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But space and time are in the world of sense. Consequently phenomena
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the world are conditionally limited, but the world itself is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limited, either conditionally or unconditionally.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For this reason, and because neither the world nor the cosmical series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of conditions to a given conditioned can be completely given, our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the cosmical quantity is given only in and through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress and not prior to it--in a collective intuition. But the regress
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: itself is really nothing more than the determining of the cosmical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantity, and cannot therefore give us any determined conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it--still less a conception of a quantity which is, in relation to a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certain standard, infinite. The regress does not, therefore, proceed to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinity (an infinity given), but only to an indefinite extent, for or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the of presenting to us a quantity--realized only in and through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress itself.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: II. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the Division
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of a Whole given in Intuition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: When I divide a whole which is given in intuition, I proceed from a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned to its conditions. The division of the parts of the whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (subdivisio or decompositio) is a regress in the series of these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions. The absolute totality of this series would be actually
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: attained and given to the mind, if the regress could arrive at simple
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts. But if all the parts in a continuous decomposition are themselves
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: divisible, the division, that is to say, the regress, proceeds from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned to its conditions in infinitum; because the conditions (the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts) are themselves contained in the conditioned, and, as the latter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is given in a limited intuition, the former are all given along with it.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This regress cannot, therefore, be called a regressus in indefinitum, as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happened in the case of the preceding cosmological idea, the regress
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in which proceeded from the conditioned to the conditions not given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contemporaneously and along with it, but discoverable only through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: empirical regress. We are not, however, entitled to affirm of a whole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this kind, which is divisible in infinitum, that it consists of an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: infinite number of parts. For, although all the parts are contained in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the intuition of the whole, the whole division is not contained therein.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The division is contained only in the progressing decomposition--in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regress itself, which is the condition of the possibility and actuality
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the series. Now, as this regress is infinite, all the members
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (parts) to which it attains must be contained in the given whole as an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: aggregate. But the complete series of division is not contained therein.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For this series, being infinite in succession and always incomplete,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot represent an infinite number of members, and still less a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition of these members into a whole.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: To apply this remark to space. Every limited part of space presented to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition is a whole, the parts of which are always spaces--to whatever
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extent subdivided. Every limited space is hence divisible to infinity.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Let us again apply the remark to an external phenomenon enclosed in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits, that is, a body. The divisibility of a body rests upon the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: divisibility of space, which is the condition of the possibility of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: body as an extended whole. A body is consequently divisible to infinity,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: though it does not, for that reason, consist of an infinite number of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It certainly seems that, as a body must be cogitated as substance
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in space, the law of divisibility would not be applicable to it as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substance. For we may and ought to grant, in the case of space, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: division or decomposition, to any extent, never can utterly annihilate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: composition (that is to say, the smallest part of space must still
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consist of spaces); otherwise space would entirely cease to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exist--which is impossible. But, the assertion on the other band that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when all composition in matter is annihilated in thought, nothing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: remains, does not seem to harmonize with the conception of substance,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which must be properly the subject of all composition and must remain,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: even after the conjunction of its attributes in space--which constituted
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a body--is annihilated in thought. But this is not the case with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: substance in the phenomenal world, which is not a thing in itself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitated by the pure category. Phenomenal substance is not an absolute
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject; it is merely a permanent sensuous image, and nothing more than
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an intuition, in which the unconditioned is not to be found.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But, although this rule of progress to infinity is legitimate and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: applicable to the subdivision of a phenomenon, as a mere occupation or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: filling of space, it is not applicable to a whole consisting of a number
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of distinct parts and constituting a quantum discretum--that is to say,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an organized body. It cannot be admitted that every part in an organized
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whole is itself organized, and that, in analysing it to infinity, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must always meet with organized parts; although we may allow that the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts of the matter which we decompose in infinitum, may be organized.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For the infinity of the division of a phenomenon in space rests
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: altogether on the fact that the divisibility of a phenomenon is given
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only in and through this infinity, that is, an undetermined number of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: parts is given, while the parts themselves are given and determined only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in and through the subdivision; in a word, the infinity of the division
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessarily presupposes that the whole is not already divided in se.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Hence our division determines a number of parts in the whole--a number
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which extends just as far as the actual regress in the division; while,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: on the other hand, the very notion of a body organized to infinity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: represents the whole as already and in itself divided. We expect,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, to find in it a determinate, but at the same time, infinite,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: number of parts--which is self-contradictory. For we should thus have a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whole containing a series of members which could not be completed in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any regress--which is infinite, and at the same time complete in an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: organized composite. Infinite divisibility is applicable only to a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: quantum continuum, and is based entirely on the infinite divisibility
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of space, But in a quantum discretum the multitude of parts or units is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always determined, and hence always equal to some number. To what extent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a body may be organized, experience alone can inform us; and although,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so far as our experience of this or that body has extended, we may not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: have discovered any inorganic part, such parts must exist in possible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience. But how far the transcendental division of a phenomenon
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must extend, we cannot know from experience--it is a question which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience cannot answer; it is answered only by the principle of reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which forbids us to consider the empirical regress, in the analysis of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: extended body, as ever absolutely complete.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Concluding Remark on the Solution of the Transcendental Mathematical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Ideas--and Introductory to the Solution of the Dynamical Ideas.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We presented the antinomy of pure reason in a tabular form, and we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: endeavoured to show the ground of this self-contradiction on the part
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of reason, and the only means of bringing it to a conclusion--namely, by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: declaring both contradictory statements to be false. We represented
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in these antinomies the conditions of phenomena as belonging to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditioned according to relations of space and time--which is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: usual supposition of the common understanding. In this respect, all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: dialectical representations of totality, in the series of conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to a given conditioned, were perfectly homogeneous. The condition was
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always a member of the series along with the conditioned, and thus the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: homogeneity of the whole series was assured. In this case the regress
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: could never be cogitated as complete; or, if this was the case, a member
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: really conditioned was falsely regarded as a primal member, consequently
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as unconditioned. In such an antinomy, therefore, we did not consider
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the object, that is, the conditioned, but the series of conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belonging to the object, and the magnitude of that series. And thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: arose the difficulty--a difficulty not to be settled by any decision
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regarding the claims of the two parties, but simply by cutting the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: knot--by declaring the series proposed by reason to be either too long
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or too short for the understanding, which could in neither case make its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions adequate with the ideas.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But we have overlooked, up to this point, an essential difference
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existing between the conceptions of the understanding which reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: endeavours to raise to the rank of ideas--two of these indicating a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematical, and two a dynamical synthesis of phenomena. Hitherto, it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: was necessary to signalize this distinction; for, just as in our general
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of all transcendental ideas, we considered them under
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomenal conditions, so, in the two mathematical ideas, our discussion
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is concerned solely with an object in the world of phenomena. But as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we are now about to proceed to the consideration of the dynamical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions of the understanding, and their adequateness with ideas, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must not lose sight of this distinction. We shall find that it opens up
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to us an entirely new view of the conflict in which reason is involved.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, while in the first two antinomies, both parties were dismissed, on
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the ground of having advanced statements based upon false hypothesis; in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the present case the hope appears of discovering a hypothesis which may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be consistent with the demands of reason, and, the judge completing the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: statement of the grounds of claim, which both parties had left in an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unsatisfactory state, the question may be settled on its own merits,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not by dismissing the claimants, but by a comparison of the arguments on
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: both sides. If we consider merely their extension, and whether they are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: adequate with ideas, the series of conditions may be regarded as all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: homogeneous. But the conception of the understanding which lies at the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: basis of these ideas, contains either a synthesis of the homogeneous
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (presupposed in every quantity--in its composition as well as in its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: division) or of the heterogeneous, which is the case in the dynamical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis of cause and effect, as well as of the necessary and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contingent.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thus it happens that in the mathematical series of phenomena no other
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: than a sensuous condition is admissible--a condition which is itself a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: member of the series; while the dynamical series of sensuous conditions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: admits a heterogeneous condition, which is not a member of the series,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but, as purely intelligible, lies out of and beyond it. And thus reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is satisfied, and an unconditioned placed at the head of the series
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of phenomena, without introducing confusion into or discontinuing it,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contrary to the principles of the understanding.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, from the fact that the dynamical ideas admit a condition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena which does not form a part of the series of phenomena, arises
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a result which we should not have expected from an antinomy. In former
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cases, the result was that both contradictory dialectical statements
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: were declared to be false. In the present case, we find the conditioned
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in the dynamical series connected with an empirically unconditioned,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but non-sensuous condition; and thus satisfaction is done to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding on the one hand and to the reason on the other.* While,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: moreover, the dialectical arguments for unconditioned totality in mere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: phenomena fall to the ground, both propositions of reason may be shown
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to be true in their proper signification. This could not happen in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the case of the cosmological ideas which demanded a mathematically
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unconditioned unity; for no condition could be placed at the head of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the series of phenomena, except one which was itself a phenomenon and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently a member of the series.

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Deduction of Cosmical Events from their Causes.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There are only two modes of causality cogitable--the causality of nature
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or of freedom. The first is the conjunction of a particular state with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: another preceding it in the world of sense, the former following the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: latter by virtue of a law. Now, as the causality of phenomena is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: subject to conditions of time, and the preceding state, if it had always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existed, could not have produced an effect which would make its first
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: appearance at a particular time, the causality of a cause must itself be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: an effect--must itself have begun to be, and therefore, according to the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle of the understanding, itself requires a cause.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We must understand, on the contrary, by the term freedom, in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cosmological sense, a faculty of the spontaneous origination of a state;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the causality of which, therefore, is not subordinated to another cause
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determining it in time. Freedom is in this sense a pure transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea, which, in the first place, contains no empirical element; the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object of which, in the second place, cannot be given or determined in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: any experience, because it is a universal law of the very possibility
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of experience, that everything which happens must have a cause, that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently the causality of a cause, being itself something that has
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happened, must also have a cause. In this view of the case, the whole

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Now, let us stop here and admit it to be at least possible that reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: SECTION VII. Critique of all Theology based upon Speculative
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Principles of Reason.
