text: If by the term theology I understand the cognition of a primal being,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that cognition is based either upon reason alone (theologia rationalis)
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or upon revelation (theologia revelata). The former cogitates its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object either by means of pure transcendental conceptions, as an ens
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: originarium, realissimum, ens entium, and is termed transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: theology; or, by means of a conception derived from the nature of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: own mind, as a supreme intelligence, and must then be entitled natural
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: theology. The person who believes in a transcendental theology alone,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is termed a deist; he who acknowledges the possibility of a natural
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: theology also, a theist. The former admits that we can cognize by pure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason alone the existence of a Supreme Being, but at the same time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: maintains that our conception of this being is purely transcendental,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and that all we can say of it is that it possesses all reality, without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: being able to define it more closely. The second asserts that reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is capable of presenting us, from the analogy with nature, with a more
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: definite conception of this being, and that its operations, as the cause
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all things, are the results of intelligence and free will. The former
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: regards the Supreme Being as the cause of the world--whether by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessity of his nature, or as a free agent, is left undetermined; the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: latter considers this being as the author of the world.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Transcendental theology aims either at inferring the existence of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Supreme Being from a general experience, without any closer reference
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to the world to which this experience belongs, and in this case it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a being, through mere conceptions, without the aid of experience, and is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: then termed ontotheology.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Natural theology infers the attributes and the existence of an author of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the world, from the constitution of, the order and unity observable
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: in, the world, in which two modes of causality must be admitted to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exist--those of nature and freedom. Thus it rises from this world to a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supreme intelligence, either as the principle of all natural, or of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: all moral order and perfection. In the former case it is termed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: It may be sufficient in this place to define theoretical knowledge or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition as knowledge of that which is, and practical knowledge as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that something is, while the practical is that by which I cognize a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: or postulate it--although only from a practical point of view. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: Now I maintain that all attempts of reason to establish a theology
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: by the aid of speculation alone are fruitless, that the principles of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason as applied to nature do not conduct us to any theological truths,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unless it is founded upon the laws of morality. For all synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience; while the cognition of a Supreme Being necessitates their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: never presents us with the greatest of all possible effects, and it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: requirements of Reason, we recognize her right to assert the existence

text: only from favour, and cannot be regarded as the result or irresistible
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: APPENDIX.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Of the Regulative Employment of the Ideas of Pure Reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The result of all the dialectical attempts of pure reason not only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: confirms the truth of what we have already proved in our Transcendental
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Analytic, namely, that all inferences which would lead us beyond the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits of experience are fallacious and groundless, but it at the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time teaches us this important lesson, that human reason has a natural
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: inclination to overstep these limits, and that transcendental ideas
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are as much the natural property of the reason as categories are of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding. There exists this difference, however, that while the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: categories never mislead us, outward objects being always in perfect
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: harmony therewith, ideas are the parents of irresistible illusions, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: severest and most subtle criticism being required to save us from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: fallacies which they induce.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Whatever is grounded in the nature of our powers will be found to be in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: harmony with the final purpose and proper employment of these powers,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when once we have discovered their true direction and aim. We are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: entitled to suppose, therefore, that there exists a mode of employing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental ideas which is proper and immanent; although, when we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mistake their meaning, and regard them as conceptions of actual things,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: their mode of application is transcendent and delusive. For it is not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the idea itself, but only the employment of the idea in relation to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possible experience, that is transcendent or immanent. An idea is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employed transcendently, when it is applied to an object falsely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: believed to be adequate with and to correspond to it; imminently, when
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is applied solely to the employment of the understanding in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sphere of experience. Thus all errors of subreptio--of misapplication,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are to be ascribed to defects of judgement, and not to understanding or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Reason never has an immediate relation to an object; it relates
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immediately to the understanding alone. It is only through the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding that it can be employed in the field of experience. It
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: does not form conceptions of objects, it merely arranges them and gives
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to them that unity which they are capable of possessing when the sphere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of their application has been extended as widely as possible. Reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: avails itself of the conception of the understanding for the sole
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: purpose of producing totality in the different series. This totality the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding does not concern itself with; its only occupation is the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connection of experiences, by which series of conditions in accordance
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with conceptions are established. The object of reason is, therefore,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding and its proper destination. As the latter brings unity
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: into the diversity of objects by means of its conceptions, so the former
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: brings unity into the diversity of conceptions by means of ideas; as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it sets the final aim of a collective unity to the operations of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding, which without this occupies itself with a distributive
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unity alone.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I accordingly maintain that transcendental ideas can never be employed
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as constitutive ideas, that they cannot be conceptions of objects, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: character. But, on the other hand, they are capable of an admirable and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: CHAPTER I. The Discipline of Pure Reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Negative judgements--those which are so not merely as regards their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: they are understood by mathematicians; and that the geometrician, if
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: he employs his method in philosophy, will succeed only in building
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: card-castles, while the employment of the philosophical method in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematics can result in nothing but mere verbiage. The essential
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: business of philosophy, indeed, is to mark out the limits of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: science; and even the mathematician, unless his talent is naturally
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: circumscribed and limited to this particular department of knowledge,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot turn a deaf ear to the warnings of philosophy, or set himself
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: above its direction.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I. Of Definitions. A definition is, as the term itself indicates, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation, upon primary grounds, of the complete conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a thing within its own limits.* Accordingly, an empirical conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot be defined, it can only be explained. For, as there are in such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a conception only a certain number of marks or signs, which denote a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certain class of sensuous objects, we can never be sure that we do not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitate under the word which indicates the same object, at one time
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a greater, at another a smaller number of signs. Thus, one person may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cogitate in his conception of gold, in addition to its properties of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: weight, colour, malleability, that of resisting rust, while another
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: person may be ignorant of this quality. We employ certain signs only so
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: long as we require them for the sake of distinction; new observations
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: abstract some and add new ones, so that an empirical conception never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: remains within permanent limits. It is, in fact, useless to define a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of this kind. If, for example, we are speaking of water and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its properties, we do not stop at what we actually think by the word
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: water, but proceed to observation and experiment; and the word, with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the few signs attached to it, is more properly a designation than a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception of the thing. A definition in this case would evidently be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nothing more than a determination of the word. In the second place, no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a priori conception, such as those of substance, cause, right, fitness,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and so on, can be defined. For I can never be sure, that the clear
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: representation of a given conception (which is given in a confused
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: state) has been fully developed, until I know that the representation
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is adequate with its object. But, inasmuch as the conception, as it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presented to the mind, may contain a number of obscure representations,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which we do not observe in our analysis, although we employ them in our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: application of the conception, I can never be sure that my analysis is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: complete, while examples may make this probable, although they can never
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: demonstrate the fact. Instead of the word definition, I should rather
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employ the term exposition--a more modest expression, which the critic
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may accept without surrendering his doubts as to the completeness of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analysis of any such conception. As, therefore, neither empirical nor a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori conceptions are capable of definition, we have to see whether the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only other kind of conceptions--arbitrary conceptions--can be subjected
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to this mental operation. Such a conception can always be defined; for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I must know thoroughly what I wished to cogitate in it, as it was I who
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: created it, and it was not given to my mind either by the nature of my
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding or by experience. At the same time, I cannot say that, by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: such a definition, I have defined a real object. If the conception is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: based upon empirical conditions, if, for example, I have a conception of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a clock for a ship, this arbitrary conception does not assure me of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: existence or even of the possibility of the object. My definition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: such a conception would with more propriety be termed a declaration of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a project than a definition of an object. There are no other conceptions
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which can bear definition, except those which contain an arbitrary
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthesis, which can be constructed a priori. Consequently, the science
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of mathematics alone possesses definitions. For the object here thought
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is presented a priori in intuition; and thus it can never contain more
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: or less than the conception, because the conception of the object has
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: been given by the definition--and primarily, that is, without deriving
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the definition from any other source. Philosophical definitions are,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, merely expositions of given conceptions, while mathematical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: definitions are constructions of conceptions originally formed by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mind itself; the former are produced by analysis, the completeness of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is never demonstratively certain, the latter by a synthesis. In
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a mathematical definition the conception is formed, in a philosophical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: definition it is only explained. From this it follows:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: The definition must describe the conception completely that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is, omit none of the marks or signs of which it composed; within its own
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits, that is, it must be precise, and enumerate no more signs than
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: belong to the conception; and on primary grounds, that is to say, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limitations of the bounds of the conception must not be deduced from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: other conceptions, as in this case a proof would be necessary, and the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: so-called definition would be incapable of taking its place at the bead
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of all the judgements we have to form regarding an object.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (a) That we must not imitate, in philosophy, the mathematical usage of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: commencing with definitions--except by way of hypothesis or experiment.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: For, as all so-called philosophical definitions are merely analyses of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given conceptions, these conceptions, although only in a confused form,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must precede the analysis; and the incomplete exposition must precede
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the complete, so that we may be able to draw certain inferences from the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: characteristics which an incomplete analysis has enabled us to discover,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: before we attain to the complete exposition or definition of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception. In one word, a full and clear definition ought, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophy, rather to form the conclusion than the commencement of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: labours.* In mathematics, on the contrary, we cannot have a conception
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: prior to the definition; it is the definition which gives us the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception, and it must for this reason form the commencement of every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: chain of mathematical reasoning.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: [*Footnote: Philosophy abounds in faulty definitions, especially such as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contain some of the elements requisite to form a complete definition.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: If a conception could not be employed in reasoning before it had been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: defined, it would fare ill with all philosophical thought. But,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as incompletely defined conceptions may always be employed without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: detriment to truth, so far as our analysis of the elements contained in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: them proceeds, imperfect definitions, that is, propositions which are
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: properly not definitions, but merely approximations thereto, may be used
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: with great advantage. In mathematics, definition belongs ad esse, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophy ad melius esse. It is a difficult task to construct a proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: definition. Jurists are still without a complete definition of the idea
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of right.]
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: (b) Mathematical definitions cannot be erroneous. For the conception is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: given only in and through the definition, and thus it contains only what
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: has been cogitated in the definition. But although a definition cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be incorrect, as regards its content, an error may sometimes, although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: seldom, creep into the form. This error consists in a want of precision.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thus the common definition of a circle--that it is a curved line,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every point in which is equally distant from another point called the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: centre--is faulty, from the fact that the determination indicated by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: word curved is superfluous. For there ought to be a particular theorem,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which may be easily proved from the definition, to the effect that every
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: line, which has all its points at equal distances from another point,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must be a curved line--that is, that not even the smallest part of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it can be straight. Analytical definitions, on the other hand, may be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: erroneous in many respects, either by the introduction of signs which do
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not actually exist in the conception, or by wanting in that completeness
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which forms the essential of a definition. In the latter case, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: definition is necessarily defective, because we can never be fully
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: certain of the completeness of our analysis. For these reasons, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: method of definition employed in mathematics cannot be imitated in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: philosophy.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. Of Axioms. These, in so far as they are immediately certain, are a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: priori synthetical principles. Now, one conception cannot be connected
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: synthetically and yet immediately with another; because, if we wish to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proceed out of and beyond a conception, a third mediating cognition is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: necessary. And, as philosophy is a cognition of reason by the aid
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of conceptions alone, there is to be found in it no principle which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: deserves to be called an axiom. Mathematics, on the other hand, may
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possess axioms, because it can always connect the predicates of an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object a priori, and without any mediating term, by means of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: construction of conceptions in intuition. Such is the case with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition: Three points can always lie in a plane. On the other hand,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: no synthetical principle which is based upon conceptions, can ever
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be immediately certain (for example, the proposition: Everything that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: happens has a cause), because I require a mediating term to connect
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the two conceptions of event and cause--namely, the condition of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: time-determination in an experience, and I cannot cognize any such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principle immediately and from conceptions alone. Discursive principles
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are, accordingly, very different from intuitive principles or axioms.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The former always require deduction, which in the case of the latter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: may be altogether dispensed with. Axioms are, for this reason, always
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-evident, while philosophical principles, whatever may be the degree
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of certainty they possess, cannot lay any claim to such a distinction.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: No synthetical proposition of pure transcendental reason can be so
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: evident, as is often rashly enough declared, as the statement, twice two
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are four. It is true that in the Analytic I introduced into the list of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principles of the pure understanding, certain axioms of intuition; but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the principle there discussed was not itself an axiom, but served merely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to present the principle of the possibility of axioms in general, while
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it was really nothing more than a principle based upon conceptions. For
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it is one part of the duty of transcendental philosophy to establish
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the possibility of mathematics itself. Philosophy possesses, then, no
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: axioms, and has no right to impose its a priori principles upon thought,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: until it has established their authority and validity by a thoroughgoing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: deduction.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. Of Demonstrations. Only an apodeictic proof, based upon intuition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can be termed a demonstration. Experience teaches us what is, but it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cannot convince us that it might not have been otherwise. Hence a proof
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon empirical grounds cannot be apodeictic. A priori conceptions, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: discursive cognition, can never produce intuitive certainty or evidence,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: however certain the judgement they present may be. Mathematics alone,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: therefore, contains demonstrations, because it does not deduce its
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition from conceptions, but from the construction of conceptions,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is, from intuition, which can be given a priori in accordance with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conceptions. The method of algebra, in equations, from which the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: correct answer is deduced by reduction, is a kind of construction--not
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: geometrical, but by symbols--in which all conceptions, especially those
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the relations of quantities, are represented in intuition by signs;
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and thus the conclusions in that science are secured from errors by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: fact that every proof is submitted to ocular evidence. Philosophical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition does not possess this advantage, it being required to consider
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the general always in abstracto (by means of conceptions), while
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematics can always consider it in concreto (in an individual
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intuition), and at the same time by means of a priori representation,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whereby all errors are rendered manifest to the senses. The
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: former--discursive proofs--ought to be termed acroamatic proofs,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rather than demonstrations, as only words are employed in them, while
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: demonstrations proper, as the term itself indicates, always require a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reference to the intuition of the object.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It follows from all these considerations that it is not consonant with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the nature of philosophy, especially in the sphere of pure reason, to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employ the dogmatical method, and to adorn itself with the titles and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: insignia of mathematical science. It does not belong to that order, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: can only hope for a fraternal union with that science. Its attempts at
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mathematical evidence are vain pretensions, which can only keep it back
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from its true aim, which is to detect the illusory procedure of reason
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: when transgressing its proper limits, and by fully explaining and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: analysing our conceptions, to conduct us from the dim regions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: speculation to the clear region of modest self-knowledge. Reason must
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not, therefore, in its transcendental endeavours, look forward with such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: confidence, as if the path it is pursuing led straight to its aim,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nor reckon with such security upon its premisses, as to consider it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unnecessary to take a step back, or to keep a strict watch for errors,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which, overlooked in the principles, may be detected in the arguments
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves--in which case it may be requisite either to determine these
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: principles with greater strictness, or to change them entirely.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: I divide all apodeictic propositions, whether demonstrable or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: immediately certain, into dogmata and mathemata. A direct synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proposition, based on conceptions, is a dogma; a proposition of the same
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: kind, based on the construction of conceptions, is a mathema. Analytical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgements do not teach us any more about an object than what was
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contained in the conception we had of it; because they do not extend our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition beyond our conception of an object, they merely elucidate the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conception. They cannot therefore be with propriety termed dogmas. Of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the two kinds of a priori synthetical propositions above mentioned, only
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: those which are employed in philosophy can, according to the general
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mode of speech, bear this name; those of arithmetic or geometry would
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not be rightly so denominated. Thus the customary mode of speaking
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: confirms the explanation given above, and the conclusion arrived at,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that only those judgements which are based upon conceptions, not on the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: construction of conceptions, can be termed dogmatical.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Thus, pure reason, in the sphere of speculation, does not contain a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: single direct synthetical judgement based upon conceptions. By means
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of ideas, it is, as we have shown, incapable of producing synthetical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: judgements, which are objectively valid; by means of the conceptions of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the understanding, it establishes certain indubitable principles, not,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: however, directly on the basis of conceptions, but only indirectly by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: means of the relation of these conceptions to something of a purely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: contingent nature, namely, possible experience. When experience is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presupposed, these principles are apodeictically certain, but in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: themselves, and directly, they cannot even be cognized a priori. Thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the given conceptions of cause and event will not be sufficient for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the demonstration of the proposition: Every event has a cause. For this
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason, it is not a dogma; although from another point of view, that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience, it is capable of being proved to demonstration. The proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: term for such a proposition is principle, and not theorem (although
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it does require to be proved), because it possesses the remarkable
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: peculiarity of being the condition of the possibility of its own ground
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of proof, that is, experience, and of forming a necessary presupposition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION III. The Discipline of Pure Reason in Hypothesis.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: This critique of reason has now taught us that all its efforts to extend
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the bounds of knowledge, by means of pure speculation, are utterly
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: fruitless. So much the wider field, it may appear, lies open to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hypothesis; as, where we cannot know with certainty, we are at liberty
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to make guesses and to form suppositions.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Imagination may be allowed, under the strict surveillance of reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to invent suppositions; but, these must be based on something that is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perfectly certain--and that is the possibility of the object. If we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are well assured upon this point, it is allowable to have recourse to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supposition in regard to the reality of the object; but this supposition
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: must, unless it is utterly groundless, be connected, as its ground of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: explanation, with that which is really given and absolutely certain.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Such a supposition is termed a hypothesis.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: It is beyond our power to form the least conception a priori of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possibility of dynamical connection in phenomena; and the category
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the pure understanding will not enable us to excogitate any such
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: connection, but merely helps us to understand it, when we meet with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it in experience. For this reason we cannot, in accordance with the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: categories, imagine or invent any object or any property of an object
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not given, or that may not be given in experience, and employ it in a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: hypothesis; otherwise, we should be basing our chain of reasoning upon
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: mere chimerical fancies, and not upon conceptions of things. Thus, we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: have no right to assume the existence of new powers, not existing in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nature--for example, an understanding with a non-sensuous intuition,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: a force of attraction without contact, or some new kind of substances
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: occupying space, and yet without the property of impenetrability--and,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently, we cannot assume that there is any other kind of community
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: among substances than that observable in experience, any kind of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presence than that in space, or any kind of duration than that in time.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In one word, the conditions of possible experience are for reason the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: only conditions of the possibility of things; reason cannot venture
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to form, independently of these conditions, any conceptions of things,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: because such conceptions, although not self-contradictory, are without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: object and without application.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The conceptions of reason are, as we have already shown, mere ideas, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: do not relate to any object in any kind of experience. At the same time,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: they do not indicate imaginary or possible objects. They are purely
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the faculties, form the basis of the regulative principles for the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: It is a humiliating consideration for human reason that it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: secure from attack or usurpation. The greatest, and perhaps the only,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: have some reason, however, to expect that, in the only other way that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: I understand by a canon a list of the a priori principles of the proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employment of certain faculties of cognition. Thus general logic, in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its analytical department, is a formal canon for the faculties of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: understanding and reason. In the same way, Transcendental Analytic was
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: seen to be a canon of the pure understanding; for it alone is competent
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to enounce true a priori synthetical cognitions. But, when no proper
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employment of a faculty of cognition is possible, no canon can exist.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: But the synthetical cognition of pure speculative reason is, as has been
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for the speculative exercise of this faculty--for its speculative
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION I. Of the Ultimate End of the Pure Use of Reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: There exists in the faculty of reason a natural desire to venture beyond
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the field of experience, to attempt to reach the utmost bounds of all
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: cognition by the help of ideas alone, and not to rest satisfied until
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: it has fulfilled its course and raised the sum of its cognitions into a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: self-subsistent systematic whole. Is the motive for this endeavour to be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: found in its speculative, or in its practical interests alone?
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Setting aside, at present, the results of the labours of pure reason in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: its speculative exercise, I shall merely inquire regarding the problems
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the solution of which forms its ultimate aim, whether reached or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not, and in relation to which all other aims are but partial and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: intermediate. These highest aims must, from the nature of reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: possess complete unity; otherwise the highest interest of humanity could
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: not be successfully promoted.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The transcendental speculation of reason relates to three things: the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: freedom of the will, the immortality of the soul, and the existence of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: God. The speculative interest which reason has in those questions is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: very small; and, for its sake alone, we should not undertake the labour
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of transcendental investigation--a labour full of toil and ceaseless
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: struggle. We should be loth to undertake this labour, because the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: discoveries we might make would not be of the smallest use in the sphere
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of concrete or physical investigation. We may find out that the will is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: free, but this knowledge only relates to the intelligible cause of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: volition. As regards the phenomena or expressions of this will, that is,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our actions, we are bound, in obedience to an inviolable maxim, without
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which reason cannot be employed in the sphere of experience, to explain
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: these in the same way as we explain all the other phenomena of nature,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that is to say, according to its unchangeable laws. We may have
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: discovered the spirituality and immortality of the soul, but we cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: employ this knowledge to explain the phenomena of this life, nor the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: peculiar nature of the future, because our conception of an incorporeal
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: nature is purely negative and does not add anything to our knowledge,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and the only inferences to be drawn from it are purely fictitious. If,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: again, we prove the existence of a supreme intelligence, we should be
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: able from it to make the conformity to aims existing in the arrangement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the world comprehensible; but we should not be justified in deducing
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from it any particular arrangement or disposition, or inferring any
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: where it is not perceived. For it is a necessary rule of the speculative
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: use of reason that we must not overlook natural causes, or refuse to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: listen to the teaching of experience, for the sake of deducing what we
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: know and perceive from something that transcends all our knowledge.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: In one word, these three propositions are, for the speculative reason,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: always transcendent, and cannot be employed as immanent principles in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to the objects of experience; they are, consequently, of no use
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to us in this sphere, being but the valueless results of the severe but
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: unprofitable efforts of reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: perfectly useless, while Reason uses her utmost endeavours to induce us
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to admit them, it is plain that their real value and importance relate
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: to our practical, and not to our speculative interest.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: conditions of the exercise of free volition are empirical, reason can
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: are aimed at by our inclinations, into one ultimate end--that of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: guidance towards the aims set up by the senses, and is incompetent to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: world. Now, as this problem relates to our in reference to the highest
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: We must take care, however, in turning our attention to an object which
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is foreign* to the sphere of transcendental philosophy, not to injure
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: transcendental, and excluding all psychological, that is, empirical,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: elements.

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: I have to remark, in the first place, that at present I treat of the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ground of explanation in the phenomenal world, but is itself a problem
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: for pure reason. A will is purely animal (arbitrium brutum) when it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: determined by sensuous impulses or instincts only, that is, when it is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: independently of sensuous impulses, consequently by motives presented by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason alone, is called a free will (arbitrium liberum); and everything
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which is connected with this free will, either as principle or
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be proved from experience alone. For the human will is not determined
title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: our sensuous faculty of desire. But these considerations of what is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: desirable in relation to our whole state, that is, is in the end good
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: and useful, are based entirely upon reason. This faculty, accordingly,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: sphere, is to inquire into the rule of conduct which reason has to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: present. Experience demonstrates to us the existence of practical
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to its causal power of commencing a series of phenomena--should
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be independent of all sensuous determining causes; and thus it seems to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be in opposition to the law of nature and to all possible experience.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Reason conducted us, in its speculative use, through the field of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: experience and, as it can never find complete satisfaction in that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: reason can be employed in a practical sphere, and whether it will here
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: as we have just stated them. We shall thus ascertain whether, from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the point of view of its practical interest, reason may not be able to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: supply us with that which, on the speculative side, it wholly denies us.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The whole interest of reason, speculative as well as practical, is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: centred in the three following questions:
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 1. WHAT CAN I KNOW?
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 2. WHAT OUGHT I TO DO?
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: 3. WHAT MAY I HOPE?
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The first question is purely speculative. We have, as I flatter myself,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: exhausted all the replies of which it is susceptible, and have at last
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: found the reply with which reason must content itself, and with which it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: ought to be content, so long as it pays no regard to the practical. But
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from the two great ends to the attainment of which all these efforts of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: pure reason were in fact directed, we remain just as far removed as if
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: we had consulted our ease and declined the task at the outset. So far,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: then, as knowledge is concerned, thus much, at least, is established,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: that, in regard to those two problems, it lies beyond our reach.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The second question is purely practical. As such it may indeed fall
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: within the province of pure reason, but still it is not transcendental,
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: but moral, and consequently cannot in itself form the subject of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: criticism.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The third question: If I act as I ought to do, what may I then hope?--is
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: at once practical and theoretical. The practical forms a clue to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: question. For all hoping has happiness for its object and stands in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: precisely the same relation to the practical and the law of morality as
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: SECTION III. Of Opinion, Knowledge, and Belief.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: The holding of a thing to be true is a phenomenon in our understanding
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which may rest on objective grounds, but requires, also, subjective
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: causes in the mind of the person judging. If a judgement is valid for
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: every rational being, then its ground is objectively sufficient, and it
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is termed a conviction. If, on the other hand, it has its ground in the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: particular character of the subject, it is termed a persuasion.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Persuasion is a mere illusion, the ground of the judgement, which lies
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: solely in the subject, being regarded as objective. Hence a judgement
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of this kind has only private validity--is only valid for the individual
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: who judges, and the holding of a thing to be true in this way cannot
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be communicated. But truth depends upon agreement with the object, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: consequently the judgements of all understandings, if true, must be in
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: agreement with each other (consentientia uni tertio consentiunt inter
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: se). Conviction may, therefore, be distinguished, from an external point
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of view, from persuasion, by the possibility of communicating it and by
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: showing its validity for the reason of every man; for in this case the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: presumption, at least, arises that the agreement of all judgements with
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: each other, in spite of the different characters of individuals, rests
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: upon the common ground of the agreement of each with the object, and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: thus the correctness of the judgement is established.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Persuasion, accordingly, cannot be subjectively distinguished from
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: CHAPTER III. The Architectonic of Pure Reason.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: By the term architectonic I mean the art of constructing a system.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Without systematic unity, our knowledge cannot become science; it will
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: be an aggregate, and not a system. Thus architectonic is the doctrine of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the scientific in cognition, and therefore necessarily forms part of our
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: methodology.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: Reason cannot permit our knowledge to remain in an unconnected and
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: rhapsodistic state, but requires that the sum of our cognitions should
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: constitute a system. It is thus alone that they can advance the ends
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of reason. By a system I mean the unity of various cognitions under one
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: idea. This idea is the conception--given by reason--of the form of a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: whole, in so far as the conception determines a priori not only the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: limits of its content, but the place which each of its parts is to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: occupy. The scientific idea contains, therefore, the end and the form of
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the whole which is in accordance with that end. The unity of the end, to
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: which all the parts of the system relate, and through which all have a
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: relation to each other, communicates unity to the whole system, so that
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: the absence of any part can be immediately detected from our knowledge
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: of the rest; and it determines a priori the limits of the system, thus
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: excluding all contingent or arbitrary additions. The whole is thus an
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: organism (articulatio), and not an aggregate (coacervatio); it may grow
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: from within (per intussusceptionem), but it cannot increase by external
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: additions (per appositionem). It is, thus, like an animal body, the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: growth of which does not add any limb, but, without changing their
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: proportions, makes each in its sphere stronger and more active.
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

text: is, a content and an arrangement of parts determined a priori by the
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: 1. In relation to the object of the cognition of reason, philosophers
title: The Critique of Pure Reason
author: Kant, Immanuel

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

title: The Critique of Pure Reason

text: opinion, served only to confuse the ideas of the understanding.
